content:
25, 2012
A Paladin’s Steam Review: Bastion. A Narrated Story About The World Falling Apart.Genre: Fantasy isometric hack and slash aRPGDeveloped and Published by: Supergiant Games & Warner Bros. Interactive EntertainmentPlatform: Windows, Mac, Linux, iOS, PS3 and Xbox360. Business Model: Base Game.Copy Purchased by Myself Overall Gameplay ThoughtsThis hack and slash aRPG has the player controlling Kid, a youth surviving the events of the Calamity. Said event destroyed much of the world that he knew and now he must traverse it, seeking to restore the Bastion. The Kid is a silent protagonist but the narrator following him around definitely isn’t. The narration is the main selling point of Bastion and where it got a lot of its praise from. The narrator’s deep tones are used to describe both the story, the interactions between characters and the player’s actions with an almost AI level of cognition. Falling off a ledge, getting hit by enemies, not figuring out where to go next gets either encouragement, prodding or almost sarcastic remarks from the narrator depending on the situation. But the narrator remains ever steadfast, determined to help the Kid out. It won’t comment on every single action taken but it’s enough to be interesting during this four hour or so campaign.  There's the Bastion level where you’re able to trigger parts of the story plot, customize the Kid’s weaponry and choose which level to go next. On each combat level is a piece of the Bastion (shards) that you must locate (usually hidden behind bosses) in order to reassemble and power it up. On combat levels, pieces of the level come falling down from the sky so you won't always know where to go next. I’m pretty mixed on this idea. I get that they didn’t want the entire level to be seen immediately nor wanted to use darkness to hide it, but it often leads to you running into walls a lot of the time. Combat ThoughtsCombat is a repetitive hack-and-slash with guns, hammers, blades and many other assorted weapons. Kid can only have two weapons equipped along with a special ability. The special ability can be summonable monsters to special weapon attacks and require dark potions to use. The Kid can’t recover his health over time, so the player will need to keep an eye out for health potions and use them when low on health. There’s an upgrade tree for weapons that changes the ability and strength to the player’s preference. It’s a good idea to figure out what weapons you’ll like early on. Each weapon upgrade requires a unique material as well as a number of spirits/currency in order to be applied. The currency can take a while unless you wish to grind the proving ground or monster waves (remembrance) level. There's also collectible items (Mementos), Vigils that change monster behavior and stats for increasing your risk/reward. All of which help take the edge off the repetitiveness of Bastion but only a little bit. For the most part, I found I ended up setting these to what I preferred and forgetting them. Unless you visit the challenge levels and complete them for the rewards, there's not a lot to choose from in the normal course of the game. Combat is pretty solid though the main problem is definitely the lacking variety of enemies. You’ll see the majority of them pretty early on and they get reused a lot. The way to defeat them is also pretty samey. Line up a shot, hopefully triggering a power-shot which gives it an extra boost, dodge out of the way if the enemy gets too close and shoot again. Rinse and repeat. A lot of the time it can feel like long battles of attrition between the health potions and seemingly endless stream of monsters. PC Settings, Visuals and SoundtrackBastion has a reasonable selection of options to customize the experience. It does give you a selection of resolution options depending on your aspect ratio. Though anything outside of a 16:9 resolution will be letterboxed. Fullscreen is on/off though you can force borderless windowed mode through a launch option. Read about how to do that on PCGamingWiki[pcgamingwiki.com]. Visual settings are extremely limited to vertical sync on/off and anti-aliasing up to 4x. I’ll grant that it’s a 2D game so lots of graphical options are probably unnecessary. However, Bastion makes up for it with a plentiful audio menu. (Where the brightness slider is located, strangely). Music, FX and narration volume can all be adjusted here with sliders for each individual one. Keyboard, mouse and controller are all supported for Bastion though controller seems to be the preferred method. Bastion still holds up as a good looking indie title with its cartoony, colorful visual style. A style that has been very well implemented and holds up all game. The soundtrack is very well done and remains one of my favorite albums from gaming. I recommend picking up the soundtrack[supergiantgames.bandcamp.com] after you've finished playing the game.Final ThoughtsBastion is a solid experience from beginning to end. The narration is very well done, constantly keeping the player engaged and not getting overbearing or annoying. The story and combat are both solid and reasonably enjoyable for the short experience. Though I do feel like the customization/crafting system requires a bit too much grinding and the combat system can feel far too repetitive at times due to the small pool of enemies. Still, I think it's worth giving Bastion a look over, even after all this time. Read this review and more at A Paladin Without A Crusade[wp.me]

content:
0, 2014
												Bastion is a beautiful game. The game play flows well, very intuitive, the soundtrack is beautiful, and the artwork is gorgeous. Think a pretty version of Diablo. You hack and slash your way through amazingly well fleshed out environments and are able to customize the upgrades your weapons. The music is amazing, so I'd recommend buying the version with the soundtrack included. The narrator has a rich, smooth, cowboy voice and the storyline is intriguing. It's never boring, and although the enemies don't have many variety, the colorful worlds bring this game to life. I played this on a PC and had no troubles with the controls what so ever. This game is not easy however. You can however chose to have unlimited amounts of lives which helps greatly, especially when you don't care to dodge or block any of the attacks being tossed your way. Great game. 9/10

content:
ber 26, 2014
												Bastion is a very stylized isometric action game in which you play a young character who finds himself awaken shortly after the apocalypse. As you explore, the world fills in around you. Over the course of the game, you pick up a variety of weapons, powers, abilities, and even penalties you can equip to give yourself better rewards, all while working your way through the areas and story.Bastion's strengths are three main areas: first, how it tells the story. The actions of the player are narrated by a fantastic voice actor, providing a feeling of having the tale be told as you play it out, which is very unique among games. Secondly, it has an amazing soundtrack, which I don't know exactly how to describe - maybe Electronic Folk? Anyway, it absolutely has one of the best soundtracks of any game I've ever played. Finally, the story itself, which I obviously don't want to spoil in the review, so I'll leave you to that.There's a fair amount of replayability and challenges to complete if the player is so inclined - I personally chose to play through once and enjoyed it as that. At any rate, the most important thing is this: buy this game, and when you do, buy the soundtrack.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												It's wonderful that in the days of the AAA triumph and corporations tightening their grip around the gaming industry's neck we can still see examples of truly wonderful pieces of art, the memories of which linger long, long after the main storyline is finished and detailes became fuzzy. And Bastion is one of the better examples of games as art, where the story is conveyed in its own unique manner that couldnt've been done in the form of a book or a movie. The plot of the game is intelligent, serious, romantic, touching - it has it all for those of us striving for a bit of fairy-tale brilliance in our boring working lives. Mechanics blend into the mix perfectly, being simple enough not to get in the way of the story, and yet complex enough to give some room for imagination and all kinds of neat little tricks that hardcore gamers are prone to. And narrating... Do I even have to mention how good it is and how fresh the whole idea feels? Supergiant Games really made a huge leap forward with this one, a leap that teaches the lesson to all developers out there, trying to make their own perfect games.Maybe over the years people will forget Bastion and move on to newer titles... But I, for one, will return to this vivid and picturesque world from time to time. Because I lived a whole new life there - short, but nonetheless beatiful.

er 20, 2015
												I like Bastion and I recommend it but it's probably not for everyone.The levels are generally well done but choosing the right weapons etc. is quite important which can lead to some frustrating trial-and-error (and a bit of grinding to level-up the weapons too perhaps)The narration and story are going to be loved by some and not others.  I started-off really enjoying it but it does get a bit wearing after a while - there's a change of tone from detatched observation to an almost "I told you so - harder than you think"-ness about it and it REVELS in revealing that you're nowhere near the end when you think you might be;0It's mostly a charming and enjoyable action game tho and so I kinda point a thumb upwards here...

er 29, 2015
												A worthwhile adventure. The rundown...The beautiful hand-drawn animations, fun combat, cool story presentation, and great music all come together to make this a great game. Gameplay: Mostly centres around combat, which is very well done, and fun for the duration of the game. As you progress you unlock cool weapons that make a lot out of simple controls. Story: Not particularly amazing BUT the narrator who guides you through the game is so cool. Really incredible presentation, with lots of style - think Firefly (the TV series) mixed into a fantasy world.To consider...- It's got a New Game+ feature so that you can hunt achievements based on modifiers you find. This is good, because the campaign is only about ~5 hours.- Really meant for a mouse and keyboard! The aiming is a little wonky with controllers.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
er 30, 2013
												Typically when a game's length comes into question, it's because of triple-digit hours on one save file. However, Bastion is one of those rare flames that petered out too quickly. Whether this complements the strong gameplay and story or serves as a complaint of an unfinished product is up to the reader. I am certain of this, though: some developer somewhere is scribbling down ways to turn Bastion's novel approach to RPGs into a multi-million dollar project. Few games can claim that they revolutionized the industry, and when they do, it's the one simple, novel idea that makes the mark. For Bastion, that's the velvety narrator who comments on nearly every aspect of gameplay. Fall off the landscape? He's got something to say about it. Thwart a boss without getting nicked? Expect a new piece of dialogue. Choose any two weapons? Prepare to methodically run through every combination of equipment. But he does more than simply comment. The narrator tells the story from the perspective of a weathered, rustic old man who's made mistakes and bears the burden of regret. At the same time, he speaks of The Kid as a champion–someone who can make things right. And that's where you come in: as The Kid, you have the opportunity to fix a sort of man-made apocalypse called the Calamity. Finding survivors along the way, The Kid has to restore power back to Bastion, the protagonists' headquarters. By finding crystals through linearly explored areas, The Kid grants Bastion energy, and buildings for some reason. Players have the illusion of choice when deciding which structure to erect, each of which grants some sort of ability or perk. The Arsenal, for example, allows the player to choose which weapons he'd like to equip, as well as a super power. Alternatively, the Shrine invokes the gods, which can make the game more difficult with a slight boost to experience and money; it's worth mentioning that the ways in which a player may increase difficulty are creative and keep the game new. However, all aspects of the game maintain a pine-fresh scent. Initially, Bastion's quick-paced, action-based gameplay is good, simple fun. Truly, without activating an idol or two, the game is a bit on the easy side. Though, should you falter, you're granted one reprieve. An additional pratfall results in running the entire level over again. Normally, a lack of checkpoints in extensive stages is a critical game design flaw, but with adjustable difficulty, this is more than fair. For those looking for a challenge and adrenaline rush, the penalty of running some of the longer levels over again can be enticing; however, those who enjoy whimsical hack-n-slashery need just avoid the idols. Although the game gets harder over time even in its vanilla state, leveling up and weapon upgrades maintain one's interest. When leveling up and choosing a potion to make The Kid stronger, players have several choices to make. Do I want more mobility when holding up my shield, or do I want to have a slight increase to critical chance? Another shop allows players to purchase gods for the Shrine, potions for leveling up perks, and even special powers for the Arsenal. Other buildings include achievements and weapon upgrading with customization. Although Bastion egregiously offers pseudo-choices the way so many other games of its ilk do, the customization, challenges, and achievements are well thought out. Valve and Kongregate will tell you with firsthand experience that easy, medium, and hard difficulty achievements are necessary if goal-setting is going to motivate players even a bit; Bastion has this covered. I completed certain auxiliary objectives without even knowing about them, while others took conscious effort and practice. Thankfully, customization makes challenges easier. In this way, some of the side missions can be thought of more as puzzles with an element of skill, but others will require finesse, alacrity, and accuracy to conquer. However, I didn't find any Excalibur equivalents, and even if I thought I did, my brother glanced over at my screen and asked me how the heck I was using that weapon combination and special power; the sentiments were reciprocated. And isn't this the goal of any designer who includes gameplay options? As alluded to in the beginning of the review, Bastion is more than just gameplay and a novel plot: it's an experience. For those who've read my King's Bounty reviews, you're probably well-aware of my love of color. Modern gaming can be so monochrome and drab that when a game as vibrant as Bastion comes along, the appeal is two-fold; not only is color in itself enticing, but we're so starved for it that our love for it is accentuated. Additionally, not only has Bastion been graced by daubs of the palette, it's extremely busy. While clutter can certainly reach a threshold, Bastion never oversteps its bounds. The developers made sure to keep the minds and eyes of its consumers occupied while not getting in their way. Another marvel of the layout is just how intuitive foreground breakables are. Many other games leave questions as to what can be examined and destroyed, and what is meant to be left alone in the background. Some may complain that foreground pillars and structures can get in the way, but this reviewer perceives that as a necessary evil given how beautiful the game is. But what would a game be without music to match the visuals? Although most of the music is forgettable, some of the tunes have lasting power. Keeping with the atmosphere of a western, the occasional acoustic guitar and harmonica make for some innovative RPG music. However, the aural highlights of Bastion lie in its vocal numbers. Simple instrumentation matched with truly melodious voices grants us serene, wistful songs. Couple this with intelligent lyrics, and Bastion leaves an imprint on anyone with a love of music or beating heart. Typically, voice acting hurts or helps in a humble way. To my knowledge, never has a game been recommended purely because of the voice acting, but Bastion might be the first. Sure, we play games to enjoy deep, fun gameplay and funny or immersive storytelling. However, what if the defining feature was its narrator, and how that story was told? Take away Bastion's voice, and that leaves a pretty good game with fun combat in a slightly unique take on a post-apocalyptic world. With the voice, Bastion isn't just a great game, it's a work of art. Never before had I anticipated a person's name in the credits of a game, just so I could seek them out online and see what they've done and what they will do. I would be absolutely astonished and floored if this is the last we hear of Logan Cunningham. Finally, the controls are what you would expect of a game of this caliber. Nigh-perfect in its intuitive rolling and hit detection, the only complaints I can make are in its auto-targeting mechanism. Due to Bastion's archaic take on defending, players may steer clear of the shield due to its unreliability. When defending, The Kid automatically faces the nearest target, which makes sense. When I close a good, long book, I always feel a little sad, as if I had just said good bye to an old friend. I want to know what happens to the characters that I grew to love, but I have to accept the end and move on. Bastion is a short game, which will run most people around five or six hours. Nevertheless, I feel that same kind of loss. Although I truly believe that Bastion could have doubled its length in terms of gameplay, I'm glad that the story didn't risk imploding on itself. Don't let anyone tell you this is a Diablo clone–that would cheapen Bastion; it needs to be heard to be believed.

r 8, 2015
This game deserved an overwhelmingly positive reviewEven if Bastion is short (just a few hours <11hrs' mine>, depending on how many challenges you're keen on passing with a gold medal rating) it's one of the few games in which the New Game+ (rewinding the whole adventure but keeping the endgame resources) was just as much fun as the first playthrough. The content might be identical, but you've probably missed out on a few platforms the first time around, so you'll have the opportunity of discovering them and testing out your untapped weapons as well.The storytelling is unique and relaxing. While you do work fighting off enemies, the narrator gives you the lowdown. The world you explore is fragmented and broken, but the visual element of the game is gorgeous. Most importantly, Bastion's music ties everything together. I can still hear the bluesy guitar line and the hurt voice of a character you meet early in the game.A game you should buy 10/10 !

												Bastion is, and will, probably always be one of my favorite games if not THE favorite game.Bastion at its core is not a really unique game, with simple but fast and fun gameplay.But Bastion relys on something else entirely,the atmosphere.The Graphics, the music, the narrator, everything fits together so perfectly.I listen to the music on my way to school pretty much evey single day. The Graphics  matches perfectly my interests - Blooming, colorfull fantasy and a somewhat Steampunky Atmosphere. Everything is wonderfully designed, every level has a unique feeling to it and nothing seems to be repetetive.And then there is the narratorBastion would probably lack something if the narrator wouldn't be there. Everytime i hear this old fella i feel like coming home, with such a wonderfull gravely and 'Old man from the west' Voice that you will easily get into the game in no time.Here is a real advice though:Go into the game with no real expectations, take your time, play it at a time where you don't have to worry about things, get yourself your favorite Drink and enjoy this wonderfull piece of an Adventure.I highly reccommend you to buy this game, especially when its on Sale.

content:
, 2014
												Bastion is by far one of the greatest games that I've played. Although the game is linear, it's easy to forget that as you slowly uncover the details of what caused the Calamity. In addition, there is a large amount of customizability with what weapons you use, and they allow for many different playstyles. In addition, instead of picking an arbitrary difficulty at the beginning (For example, if you pick between easy and hard, what makes hard more difficult than easy?), the game allows you to create your own challenge - while also rewarding you with more EXP if you choose to do so. The storytelling in the game is also phenomenal, and makes replaying the game so much more fun - because you can't catch every detail in your first play through. I've beaten the game many times and still notice something new each time. Overall, this is a great game and shows that Supergiant Games will definitely continue to be a great video game company.

content:
er 17, 2016
												This game is the bastion of a well-designed RPG, and game (heh). Now that we've got that one pun out of the way, I truly do think that Bastion is one of the best RPG games out there, especially because it focuses on untraditional aspects of a game, and focuses on making a game a piece of art.Obviously, Bastion does the RPG-part of an RPG well. The plot is pretty well-crafted (no big holes), and I truly do buy into the story of the game. The characters are well-made, and while they lack a bit of depth (the game is a bit short compared to, let's say, Skyrim), they're still pretty cool. The in-game mechanics also are pretty good, and fit into the RPG-ish genre: you run around on an isometric platform, using your weapons to defeat the many nefarious enemies you'll encounter. You upgrade (and sidegrade) your character, weapon choice, and even game difficulty as the game goes on. All things normal for an RPG, and all things done well.I think where the game excels is the concept of art, and art in the game. First of all, the game is very visually appealing. According to the creators, Supergiant Games, the entire game is hand-painted; I've got to give kudos to their painting. The landscape is breathtaking, enemies really do look and feel like enemies, and each part of the map has its own special graphical feel (e.g. forests, swamps, cities). From an audio standpoint, there's also this narrator that accompanies you around the game, and he's one of the best serious narrators I've encountered. In addition, the soundtrack is absoutely amazing. Whoever they hired to do their sound really puts you into the game: common RPG tropes like "boss-fight music" are done very well, and the atmosphere is set during troughs of playtime. I've even added some of the songs on Spotify, and that's something I rarely see from video games.The game is also replayable (there's a new game + mode), and has a mechanism called "shrines" that can make the game harder, for better rewards. Plus, as you level up and gain access to more weapons, different playstyles are available.Overall, Bastion is one of the best RPGs I've played in a long time, and I definitely think it's worth its selling price. It functions well as an RPG game, but also has the added bonus of being a well-developed piece of art. If you're someone who likes games that are both fun to play and fun to just watch and listen, Bastion's definitely the game for you.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												Once again, close friends and strangers of the internet, I'm back to review a game. I rarely feel the need to instantly write a review for a game; I generally like to replay the game so that I can see it from multiple angles (with the exception of FarCry 3-Blood Dragon. I've suffered enough. However, this game is still making my hands tremble from excitement some 12 seconds after I finished it. Without any further build-up, I give you... The Review Developed by Supergiant Games, Bastion sets place is a post apocalyptic world (Man, this steam sale I really went all out in Post-apocalyptic games) I don't really want to give too much away about the story (That's a lie, I really do want to, but for you, loyal or disloyal reader, I won't), the whole experience really is a journey more that a game. The excellent storytelling by voice actor Logan Cunningham was exceptional. This guy has the sexiest voice since Morgan Freeman. Seriously, his voice is like velvet. I loved the story all the way through. I did feel like it was balancing on the edge of getting repetitive like some kind of tight rope walker of dullness, but it never crossed that line, creating a rich game with plenty of replay value (Blood Dragon, Take note)Okay, now to something I can never seem to appreciate outside of the video gaming world.  ART!!!  This game was beautiful. It removed all need for me to go outside or even leave my chair. The way the world generated itself around you did a great many things including1. Add to the uniqueness of the game2. Create a need for completionist to search every single edge with the hope it might create a secondary pathand, subsequently3. Make REPLAY VALUE (*Cough Cough Blood Dragon)The art design of the characters, enemies, scenery and weapons was truly something to be admired. Hats off to Jen Zee, the god in human form who made this exist.The music of this game was a delicacy. I know I say this a lot with my reviews but I'm seriously considering putting the soundtrack on my phone. It always perfectly supported the art style, the story at that point and Logan Cunningham's sexy voice (Call me!)The combat was smooth and also commendable. Players had the choice of 13 different weapons (Excluding the battering ram) and were required to choose a melee and a range as well as a special move. The special moves were never over powered but they certainly did aid combat and contrasted against what was never dull combat. The combat in itself was great. There was a countering system which, though difficult to perform, were occasionally the only way to do serious damage to an enemy (This often depended on the weapons you chose.) The weapons you chose definitely affected the game. Weapons varied in range, speed and some required reloading and cooldowns. I choose to use the hammer and the duel pistols, however I'm sure everyone who's played this game will have less then positive opinions on my loadout. It really does depend on the individual play styles. The weapons could be upgraded, which was both significant and necessary to the game.Along with the main story line, there were also trials that you could do on the side for each specific weapon. Receiving a high score would earn you either third, second, or first prize depending on how quickly you completed the trial, how well you completed the trial or how many shots it took you to complete the trial. The rewards ranged from an upgrade for a specific weapon, the games currency or even a special move if you took first place. I was discouraged to say the least when I couldn't unlock the special move for my duel pistols and could have easily spent another half an hour if my fingers weren't about to start bleeding. This was a great way to add extra content and add to the depth of the game (This is the last reference I'm making to Blood Dragon)One great addition to the game was basically a wave based combat system in which you fought off waves of enemies whilst receiving back-story for one specific character. This was a great way to add depth and extra content to your game. I hope whoever came up with this idea was given a raise. (The back-story for the characters was well written and well voiced by the very sexily voiced Logan Cunningham.Finally, Something I never really explored in the game was the ability to use the shrine. This basically granted bonus XP or currency, but made huge effects onto the game (enemies respawing after you killed them, more enemies, more health and powerful enemies ect. Some shrines even did the reverse, making the game easier.Alright, if I haven't convinced you yet, go visit a doctor. This game deserves your money. Go get it now.Seriously, I'll wait.What are you waiting for?If you haven't got it yet, I'm very disappointed in you. Let's recap.Everything about this game is perfect, except that I'm not playing it right now.Anyway, needless to say, this game receives a 10/10Thanks for reading, see you next time.

content:
, 2014
												Bastion is by far one of the greatest games that I've played. Although the game is linear, it's easy to forget that as you slowly uncover the details of what caused the Calamity. In addition, there is a large amount of customizability with what weapons you use, and they allow for many different playstyles. In addition, instead of picking an arbitrary difficulty at the beginning (For example, if you pick between easy and hard, what makes hard more difficult than easy?), the game allows you to create your own challenge - while also rewarding you with more EXP if you choose to do so. The storytelling in the game is also phenomenal, and makes replaying the game so much more fun - because you can't catch every detail in your first play through. I've beaten the game many times and still notice something new each time. Overall, this is a great game and shows that Supergiant Games will definitely continue to be a great video game company.

content:
11, 2015
												The reason why I bought Bastion was because of the immense praise and positive reviews it recieved on release. That might have been a mistake on my part, since I expected it to be a lot more than what it turned out to be. I didn't get the indie gem I thought I was getting, but instead a mediocre hack n slash with some underwhelming RPG elements slapped on top. It does have one thing going for it admittedly, and that's the presentation. The isometric graphics are beautiful, they were clearly shown a lot of love, and the narration is enjoyable, even though it gets kind of irritating after a while.The gameplay on the other hand is dreadful. It may be responsive and functional, but it is incredibly dull and repetitive and offers little challenge or variation. The levels are essentially all the same, there are no puzzles or interesting gameplay elements to differentiate them, only a slight difference in color hue and tileset. There isn't much enemy variation and it just feels like you're powering through mob after mob to get a little bit of story to keep you going(and the story is only decent at best).My advice is to try the demo and see how you like it, since it will give a pretty good idea what you will do for the rest of the game. Don't believe the hype.

content:
2014
												 It's an isometric action indie game (although I don't know how being published by Warner Bros is indie but nevermind that.) This is probably the first indie non-sandbox game I’ve played. It follows through the adventures of a boy the „Kid” who’s entire race was wiped off of the face of the earth „Bastion” by a strange event called the „Calamity”. The „Kid” is trying to salvage through the remains of his civilization exploring the world trying to find clues, and certain items to restore „Bastion” to its former glory.I’ll follow the usual format of game reviews just to make it easier to read.-	Story/QuestsThe story itself is quite mediocre I’d say, there are no mind-blowing twists or hilarious moments in it. The quest mechanic are basically the same „go and fetch this and that” repeating around 16 times which can be tedious after a while. However an unique feature of the game is that EVERYTHING is narrated, no not by Morgan Freeman but by a more „macho” sounding gentleman Logan Cunningham who is also great in what he does. The narration gives an interesting vibe to the game, you feel like you’re part of the story and it feels like „living in the book”, making the fights/progression and story more immersive. The narrator also has some quirky comments when you change your loadout or accidentally fall off of a floating island which made me smile quite a few times. -	Graphics/LooksThe art of the game is beautiful. Every level has a different story, feel to it which makes you forgive the (otherwise tedious) quests. Everything is colorful, rich and vibrant. Thankfully the game doesn’t have any serious system requirements it runs easily on a laptop so you can enjoy it in its full glory. There’s not much more to say, go watch some trailers or gameplay videos :)-	Combat/GameplayThe game is very combat-centric, you don’t have much time to immerse yourself into the game or admire the scenery without getting ♥♥♥♥♥ by the various enemies. It’s like Bioshock Infinite, beautiful and interesting but you must keep on grinding through hordes of various enemies. The enemy variety is alright when you start to get bored there’s always a new type of enemy appearing. The combat itself is surprisingly fun with a great variety in weapons and combat styles. There is no quick-save or even checkpoints, a game is only saved after you successfully finish a level.You have one primary and a secondary weapon slot and a variety of weapons (ranging from katanas to muskets) which you can upgrade. You also have a special ability slot which you can use to throw grenades or place a decoy of yourself to confuse enemies. There’s supposed to be an alchemy system and stealth in the game but I didn’t really want to get into it, I stick to my guns thanks. The combat is incredibly fast-paced and hectic with tons of enemies coming at you, sometimes you even feel like you’re playing an isometric „Shoot ’em Up” dodging projectiles all the time. The game is HARD, the enemies hit hard even on easy difficulty you find yourself grasping for breath, looking for health potions and trying to survive. You have three chances to „respawn” after dying if you exceed it then you must start the level all over again. There are the usual boss batles and you should apply a different strategy for different foes.Conclusion:Bastion is a fun little game, but it has its flaws. I love reading classic literature in my free time so my expectations of a „story” are quite high when I play video games. The game is beautiful, the combat is fun but challenging, and the narration brings a refreshing change to the storytelling. I recommend it to people who like games with an unique world, and lore but who also like getting their hands dirty in frequent fights. I don’t recommend it to people who don’t like hard fast paced, crazy combat and to people who don’t like to start a level all over again. The game takes around 6-8 hours to beat, but I heard that there are two different endings so it gives some replay value (I didn't really care about the story so one playthrough was enough for me :) )Story 6/10Graphics 9/10Combat 8/10Overall 8/10Oh I forgot to mention:THE SOUNDTRACK IS F*****ING AMAZING!!!!I mean really, I was even thinking of putting it on my phone just to listen to it its so great.

content:
ry 15, 2016
												Oh man, where do I start? I absolutely LOVE this game. It is one of my favorite indie games that I've ever played (though I do still have a lot left to get around to!).The story of Bastion is definitely an interesting one, and the way you learn more of the details is relatively simple but intriguing. For instance, learning through the Dream levels turns out to be more fun than you would expect. The perspective of the characters shifts as the game goes on and it definitely has you wonder what is going on.I liked the frame of everything with the narration, but I don't want to spoil any of the story so I won't say any more. The graphics of the game are great; it is straight up beautiful to look at. Very nice sound all around, and I love the music it has. The actual vocal songs they created were amazing as well and fit the style of their scenes almost perfectly.Gameplay-wise, Bastion still continues pulling things off. There are enough unique enemies and bosses in the game to keep things interesting, and the weapons available also allow for you to test out different builds. The development of the Bastion is nice, even if you end up building everything in one playthrough (meaning you can't necessarily make a "bad" choice of what to build). But it helps tie everything into the world as a whole. Each level has a unique feeling to it and definitely keeps me focused. The training grounds for the weapons give you some nice challenges to overcome, and all of them are certainly doable. The potions you can equip further your build for Kid.All in all, Bastion is just an amazing game. It keeps you focused and interested, with next to nothing wrong with the game at all. I never got bored with it, and I never will. I have played it multiple times since it was released, and I am always excited to play it every time I return.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
15, 2016
												If you don't want to read you can watch the video review which basically says the same.


YouTube™ Video: James Elgo Reviews - Bastion 

			Views: 376		

			Game time as of this review: 5.5h Hope you enjoyed, if you want to buy this game here is the link: http://store.steampowered.com/app/107100/ Thanks for watching, join my steam group page for more...		

Bastion is a hack n' slash role playing game, however this game has some really interesting aspects that contrast from other games inside the same genre.You play as "The Kid" someone that just woke up in the middle of a catastrophe that neither the player nor the character know anything about, however we can count on the strong presence of the Narrator to enlighten us during our adventure.I want my first point on this review to be exactly about the Narrator, something that really standed out from any game I've ever played. We are used to games which story develops over time with strong interactions between characters, or with the environment however in Bastion, every interaction is very  subtle, and that's where the Narrator comes in, as someone telling and unfolding a story and interacting as much with the main character as with the player himself which is awesome. And the developers really hit gold here, since first of all the voice fits perfectly on the western theme that surrounds the game, and at the same time the voice acting is also amazing, since you can feel every emotion which helps create a certain empathy with this being, and that's something fundamental in this story.Since we're talking about voices and sounds let's jump to the soundtrack, which after the Narrator is the best aspect of the game, since it manages to develop and transform according to the story which is phenomenal. You'll understand what i mean since it's quite rare to hear a soundtrack which contain tracks with lyrics, and even though I think that including something like that is risky since it could break the atmosphere of the game, it does exactly the opposite and traps you even more on this brilliant story.Now onto the gameplay, this is up to you to decide if it is a good thing or not according to your standards but to me it felt like the combat and exploration is something secondary. Don't get me wrong, the combat is fun and this aspect of the game is very well developed with a big array of weaponry, abilities and upgrades. The developers even managed to make this part of the game more interesting with the fact that all the way to the last part of the game you unlock a new mechanic, however it didn't feel as good as the plot, which was what really kept me going.The visuals are very interesting, the 2D visuals with the isometric camera really fitted into the style, nevertheless some models seemed quite odd, as an example the main character which on some drawings shows up as someone quite slim, when you look at the model you see someone quite bulky which doesn't make much sense. Same goes for Rucks which the model doesn't look that good either.Something that also bugged me was the fact that you're being told a story and all of a sudden the game gives you the option to make a couple decisions on the final stage and to me it felt out of place, I think you should be either given more choices to make or none at all. Although i think I'll play this game again someday I can't justify playing the main storyline for 5 hours again just to make a diferent decision at the end and see an alternate ending, but if I had more choices throughout the game I could justify a second playthrough immediately after the first one.Nonetheless I consider this game to be a master piece, the story is interesting, the length feels just right and the western/badass vibe throughout the game is an amazing experience.+ Great story;+ Fun mechanics;+ Amazing Atmosphere;- Some models are just ugly;- Lack of more decisions.92% cool game!Join my Steam Group page for more reviews: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/jereviews

content:
r 11, 2014
												Buy this. Now.Seriously, this game is possibly one of the greatest games I have ever played- the story is phenominal, the characters interesting and deep, the atmosphere hauntingly beautiful, and the most important to me, it NEVER felt like an indie title. The game stars a set of four characters after the 'Calamity', a mysterious force that next to destroyed the world. You play as 'The Kid', and head to Bastion to meet "The Stranger", who narrates your story to build the Bastion and give hope to the new world. Along the way you meet Zulf, a fabulous character and probably one of the best in any game ever, and Zia- a young Singer who brings a vision of innocence and childlike wonder to the otherwise bleak world.I've played through the game three times, and every time I notice something new- some piece of narration with a second meaning, or even a theory about the world I hadn't seen before. If you can't pay for this game now, buy it when it hits the sale shelf.Overall, this is one of the most flawless games I've ever played. 10/10.

content:
4, 2015
												Play this Game.I bought Bastion back when it first showed up on Steam and I played a while but I never got the chance to finish. Recently I was looking for something different to play so I thought I'd fire Bastion up again and give it a play through. I love this game.Bastion is about a boy who "wakes up" in the middle of what the game calls the Calamity. Your story is narrated as you (this boy) progress through levels that build themselves around you. This should not be confused with procedurally generated levels, rather there's a hint of where a path should be and as you move, tiles form up around you. This is a pretty cool effect even if it's totally linnear. As you progress the story deepens, you find new weapons, upgrades, secrets etc. to battle your way through the game's enemies with a goal of restoring the Bastion, the game's home point. I never found the combat to be particularly challenging, with enemies brodacatsting attacks well before they happen and picking up fairly predictable patterns to counter. Your weapons and skills are more than strong enough to handle everything the game throws at you. You will have the opportunity to make things harder on yourself as you complete more peices of the Bastion if you wish. Weapons can be upgraded at the Bastion's forge, adding extra damage, or critical chance etc. You'll also be able to switch out skills and buy power up type items to help you along. And at the end you'll get to unlock a new game plus mode which adds a little replayability.Level design is pretty cool, as I mentioned above the world forms around you as you move along. Sometimes leading to dead ends, sometimes leading to secret areas containing upgrade materials, or new story items, even companion type characters. It's worth exploring every corner you can in these well built, beautifully rendered, but often very small areas. The story itself is at first just a narration of what you do as the game's hero character, but soon enough you'll start to feel it coalescing into something bigger. As you play, the game's narrator continues to tell the stories of the boy and various survivors of the calamity. This takes place in the game itself along with aquiring items to learn about and that help tell the history of the Bastion and it's home world and the people who inhabit it. Once things begin to move the story progresses quickly and in my opinion is told pretty masterfully. Now, Ive heard of people complaining about the narration of the game. Saying that he's too involved, or too in your face. That he never shuts up and they just want to play the game. I'm sorry to say that you can't shut the narrator off for those of you who may find him annoying. But on the other hand, he's the one telling the story, and Bastion is a story driven game so you need the narrator. I personally loved listening to him, the voice is pleasant, smooth and to me at least was nothing close to invasive. The narrator is integral to the game's story being told so you'll just have to deal with it and even if you don't like listeing to him I'm sure as things go on you'll at least be interested in what he has to say. The story itself is emotial, fairly deep and told really really well.As is usual these days the game is short, around 6 hours I think total with potential of a couple more if you complete the optional mini games. But the fact is the story is fully told in this time, so you get a feeling of completion even though you it's a short play through, and with new game plus you can double the play value and still have fun.Bastion, also has an epic sound track. "Zia's song", and the end theme "Coming Home" are two that stick out in my head. I believe the game even comes with a copy of the sound track if I remember corrctly. In conclusion, Bastion, is a beautiful, short, story driven game with an excellent story and great original music. It's inexpensive and worth a play through. Give it shot I'm sure you'll dig it.

content:
ber 16, 2014
												I cannot sing the praises of this game enough. I went into this knowing next to nothing, not even knowing how well praised it is. This has become my favorite game. The story is interesting and quite grim. There are no cutscenes or excessive text. It doesn't try to be a movie, it's a very subtle and gameplay driven story. The Narrator's voice gives Morgan Freeman a run for his money. The gameplay is fun and stays fresh for the most part. Interesting enemies and lore. The art style is beautiful, I adore how the land forms at your feet.And the soundtrack? Don't even get me started on the soundtrack. It is PHENOMENAL. I could listen to it nonstop. There is not a single song that is any less than the others. There are a few songs that have singers, which is usually a no-no in video games, but it suits the situation perfectly.The one thing that really bothers me only applies to you if you want to complete every little thing in the game like I do. It's no problem if you're a "finish the story then I'm out" kind of person. But the grinding. To buy every upgrade for every weapon, you have to beat Who Knows Where many times, or replay New Game+ multiple times. It gets stale, but I need to beat the Calamity Cannon training grounds, dammit!Bottom line, buy it. I'd wait for a Steam Sale (then again, I do for everything), but it's worth every cent. Supergiant Games deserves it so they can hopefully make more awesomeness. I can't wait to try Transistor.

content:
30, 2012
												Original review by 17 year-old Luke: "A narrator who compares with even Morgan Freeman, challenging gameplay and a deep story - with a unique storytelling style. If you have working hands: play this game."While 19 year-old Luke agrees, I feel as though there's more to say, since looking back at Bastion: it still feels like one of my most significant gaming experiences of ever.That viewpoint is perhaps somewhat nostalgic; this was one of the first real PC games I played back when I was still primarily a console gamer. So I will look back on it with that same sense of importance as Assassin's Creed 2 or Uncharted 2, the first two PlayStation 3 games I played.Nevertheless, there are elements of this game that make it recommendable to anyone, despite its personal significance to myself and the close friends who played and discussed it with me back then.Firstly, the narration is exquisite - and yes, past-luke, it does compare to Morgan Freeman. The narration really draws you into the world quite quickly, and although I don't have a vivid memory of the world that the game was set in, I do have a vivid memory of the (protagonist) kid's adventure through that world. The narration is your first contact with that world, right into the game's ending moments - which I won't spoil, but I will say that they are very well crafted from a storytelling perspective.Secondly, I said the game had challenging gameplay. I'm not sure why I said that really. I did die a few times, but that was just because I wasn't used to playing with a keyboard and mouse more than anything. As James (M!dD3) points out in his comment, the gameplay is straightforward and simple, with a wide array of weapons to choose from and experiment with. And for those who want more out of a game's challenge - there are indeed way to buff your enemies in the name of bragging rights.For me though, the gameplay wasn't a prominent factor. More important was the music, the soundtrack is amazing and undefinable by common genres. I've heard it described as "acoustic frontier trip-hop", so....yeah. Lovely. I still listen to that soundtrack today, and everyone I've encouraged to listen to it has loved the sounds: from friends my age, to adults, to grandparents.However, a game's soundtrack isn't rated by the quality of the sounds alone; in-game that is an irrelevant quality. But the music fits the game perfectly. I can still recall the chilling hammer-on-stone clangs of "mine, windbag, mine' as I entered an eerie stage and began to learn more of the truth of the strange world. And don't even get me started on "build that wall" and "mother, I'm here" - or better yet, their lovechild: "setting sail, coming home", to this day one of my favourite songs.The artstyle is equally captivating while in game, there's a certain childish element to the designs that mix with the seriousness of the plot - summing up the kid's overburdened mindset perfectly. There's a reason that kid looks so melancholy on the game's cover art.And I suppose that brings me to the final element that I mentioned, the game's "deep plot". Yes, well, that's one way to put it. Let me just say the decisions I made in that game hold true to the way I intend to continue to view my failures and embrace the future for the rest of my life. That is by no means an overstatement, or some pretentious interpretation of the game's plot. This game is simple and important, that's all there is to it. So, as past-luke rightfully said: "if you have working hands: play this game."Storytelling: 1/1Plot: 1/1Gameplay: [who even cares, just play it]/10Visuals: 9/10 (impressively beautiful, but not the recommendation-point on this one)Soundtrack: 11/10 (the music itself is 100% recommendable, even if you don't play the game - check it out right now if you're reading this)Do I get a boner just thinking about this game?: Yes/Yes

content:
r 16, 2013
												Bastion is an amazing indie title about world after apocalypse. You control silent protagonist which is narrated by someone who has replaced his vocal cords with  chocolate candy and that voice guides the protagonist through levels. Throughout progression you find 2 human survivors and 4 pets that will accompany you in Bastion when you return from your quest. I liked the part where you picked up Zia, the  singer. Her song is so beautiful that you don't want her to stop, but unfortunatelly you have to. I think it's the best episode in the whole game. The story is quite interesting and engaging, because you'll care about your new found friends and pets. Gameplay is quite fun, you run around and smash various creatures with your weapon of choice (mine was Brushers Pike and Mortar) and retrieve Cores and Crystal shards to make Bastion functional again. You get quite big weapon arsenal and passive abilities (which comes in the shape of alcohol) to chose from. If you wondering whenever you should buy it the answer is yes, definately fun, aestheticly pleasing and good quality product. 8/10

content:
ber 16, 2013
												One of my all time favorite games.  Bastion tells the tale of "The Kid", (possibly) a young man waking up in the aftermath of what's deemed "The Calamity," a disaster that overtook the entirety of Caelondia.  From there, you're on a journey to restore the Bastion, a place of sanctuary for when the situation arose.The story creates a perfect world where details are up to the player's interpretation, being quite scarce and vague overall on the land itself, and the landmarks which litter it.  Throughout the game, you're given a beautifully executed narrative by Logan Cunningham, who - with every step of the way - informs you of your progress as you roll along, and provides interesting pieces that could tell a thing or two about the land's past, or your own. The game is played from an Isometric perspective, with that being the camera being held at around an seventy-five degree angle.  Gameplay can often be mixed up to however your choosing with two weapon slots for you to make use of. Two melee weapons or two devastating range weapons?  Sure, why not. The game can provide wider mix of playstyles as well, having access to a special skill to make use of between your two weapons, it can turn the tide of battle in your favor.  Furthermore, the game can give you special "tonics" that you can equip within the game's Distillery that can give you a boost to help your survive longer in battle, or to compliment your playstyle of being at a distance or up close.With it's hand drawn art, intricate story, fairly diverse gameplay, deep narrative, and great soundtrack, I'd say this game is well worth the money you put into it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 16, 2015
												"Abstract" "Indie" games is where all the (K)ool Kids are. Just about recently, gamers are regularly met with a surfeit of these indie games that have a history of HYPE. Too bad most of them turn out to be vaporware or pretentious garbage. But there is that minute gleam of light that promises quality. Supergiant Games, thankfully, ends up being one of the few that actually develop decent games. Bastion, the game in question, is not one that should be adjudged "decent", but rather, astounding. Far from flawless, as this game is locked at 30 frames (Just, why?), but an overall stellar game that is worth every penny, or whatever crap currency you wield.Meet the Kid. One of the handful of survivors that has endured the Calamity. This catastrophic event brought the whole world to ruin. He sets off to the Bastion, where he is greeted by Rucks, the Stranger, with words claiming that the recent disaster can be undone. By constructing the Bastion back to health with monument cores and shards there are odds of restoring Caelondia and its neighbor lands to a time before hell unleashed, hence the title of this game. Throughout the Kid's travels to seek out the materials needed, players will learn more about the world and its people and you get to learn the backstories of the few survivors you come across as the game progresses. It might seem engrossing, but the story is where Bastion falls shortest. The journey with the Kid was complete in every angle it is viewed in, but it was also rushed from start to end, and had inadequate time to develop. Build-up starts to occur profusely around the last third of the game, only to conclude in some half-baked ending that proved to be unfufilling. Despite the mediocre narrative, Bastion is a feast for the eyes and ears due to it's gorgeous presentation.It is not an overstatement when it is said that this game has the potential to be sold solely on it's presentation. Hell, some have avowed that they bought the soundtrack before the damn game. It's just that damn delicious. Bastion's visuals is where that abstract tag comes into play, because it is most certainly what most reckon to be unconventional. The playing stage constructs itself as you tread along the path and the camera is complimented by a shiny filter, and other things I won't bother typing as it's better experienced than read. The soundtrack, done by composer Darren Korb, is brimful with impressive songs that seemlessly attach to the rest of the presentation. I'm not one that gushes over video game OSTs, but this one is pretty damn good, and I'm convinced everyone that isn't a moron agrees.If only it wasn't locked at thirty frames...that idea bothers me way to f****** much.Even with such wondrous superficial values, a game is crap if it isn't fun, and it is relieving to know that Bastion succeeds in this fundamental aspect too. Not much can be said about it however, it's just the average action-adventure game with a few tweaks that enable it to distinguish itself from the rest. The Kid can be equipped with 2 weapons at once and he has a "secret" move, and by, of course, playing the game (no way), the Kid is met with unlocks in his arsenal and attributes that gradually form him to an impetus of destruction by the end of the game. Sounds a little, unamusing, but this is without the mention of the copious ways one can up their game. The game played vanilla is laughably easy, but there are shrine idols that can unexpectedly rise its difficulty, which is recommended. There are also Vigils to complete for moneys, and wave-based side missions to earn more moneys and achievements, and a New Game Plus option that actually bears fruit! All of this will keep many entertained for a appreciable amount of time, around 20 hours or so maximum.There's more to be said, but I'm done. Bastion is a worthwhile game that I'm sure many have already invested their time in, and I hope people continue to pick this up. Supergiant Games is a talented developer, and they only demonstrate so with this installation. Where it fails in storytelling makes up in well-done game-structure and incredible graphics and sound. I'm looking foward to playing more entries from this group.Still haven't played Transistor at the time of this review, so I need to get to that quick.

ber 24, 2014
												Bastion is a fine action-adventure game set in a fantastic world after a near apocalyptic event. The scenery is superb, beautiful places that show some of this world's former glory. The gameplay is quite varied, as there is a wide variety of weapons, each with their respective upgrades and secret skills, that you can combine in every way you want. You can also customize the difficulty by invoking different gods that will make foes stronger in a variety of ways, while providing you with greater rewards.The soundtrack is another strong point for this game. Each song seems fitting to the situation you're currently in, and there's plenty of them.Finally, the story is very well crafted. The narration aspect is quite interesting, and as you progress, it begins to make more and more sense. Not to mention that a second playthrough, in New Game+, will add new details.All in all, a highly recommendable game.

												Bastion: The first game made by Supergiant Games. Also the first amazing game they created.Bastion's a hack and slash action-adventure game, and a great one at that. You play as "The Kid", who stumbles upon the Bastion after the Calamity's wiped pretty much everything out. Your job? Restore the Bastion. You'll go through a relatively short, but well written story, with a small amount of replayability and lots of challenges along the way.Pros: -Great soundtrack-Great story-The game looks amazing with the color/lighting scheme-Amazing narration-Somewhat challenging achievements for the completionist-Many different ways to play the game, from difficulty to weaponsCons:-Not too much replayability - After NG+/Score Attack, you're pretty much done.Overall:Easily in my Top 10 Favorite Games. A great soundtrack + stellar narration + variety of playstyles + a great story + a fantastic looking game? That's a combo for a successful game right there. At $15, it might seem slightly overpriced, but take my word for it - It's not. That said, if you can pick it up for even a penny less, do so, as you for sure won't regret it.

content:
er 28, 2013
												I recently reviewed this game for my game review blog, Five Penny Review. If you enjoy this review, please visit my page:http://fivepennyreview.blogspot.com/2013/04/bastion.htmlWhat sets this game apart?Conceptually, Bastion could be considered a fairly typical action RPG.  It features a silent protagonist, a small cast of enemies, a selection of weapons for which you develop new skills as you progress, and a combat system heavy on combos and dodge rolling.  What makes it unique is its presentation, and to say that Bastion is an artistic endeavor would be an understatement.  The art creates a world somewhere between catastrophe and storybook, the music has a multicultural feel that creates something familiar but foreign.  The only character to speak is the narrator, who is a constant presence in the game and provides information about the world, the characters, and your course of action, serving as both storyteller and tutorial.  The way this was accomplished creates an experience that envelops you in what would otherwise be a decent game.What is the difficulty factor?The tutorials for Bastion are pretty straight forward, and the controls are fairly simple to pick up and play.  The narrator also does a good job providing little hints for moving forward, especially early in the game.  The timing for dodge rolling, blocking with your shield, and even just attacking can take some time to master and feel a bit clumsy, especially given the differences in the available weapons.  The weapon proving grounds provide a good method for mastering the techniques for various weapons.As far as the challenge curve goes, Bastion does a great job of starting off easy and escalating slowly to a proper difficulty.  The proving grounds and dream sequences allow you to build up your level and money, often while earning new techniques.  If you aren’t feeling challenged, the shrine allows you to drastically increase the difficulty of specific aspects of the game to increase your rewards, allowing you to customize the difficulty of the game in a unique way.Does it use media effectively?Bastion has a very stylized appearance that gives it a persistent otherworldly feeling, like you are experiencing a dream or watching the illustrations of a story book.  The enemies and foreground objects are often strange and brightly colored, the world itself is made up of chunks of ground floating in mid-air that form as you progress, and the backgrounds consist of little more than gradient colors and clouds.  The culmination of this look is a sense of nihilistic beauty, which seems appropriate in drawing the audience in to the story of the survivors of a world shattering apocalypse.The music in Bastion is a bit hard to describe, both because of its occasional strangeness and the obvious scope of its influences.  At its core there is often a folksy acoustic guitar, but many of the tracks feature distinctly eastern sounds as well.  The lyrics are simple and poignant, and the vocal tracks have a haunting beauty to them.  Ultimately, the music has the same effect as the visuals, to draw you in to a place that is both alien and beautiful, and reminding you of what has been lost to the world you explore.Best moment in the game?While not a specific moment, the best thing about this game to me was Rucks, the narrator.  Voice actor Logan Cunningham did a great job creating a character that sounded familiar and warm, further connecting you to what could otherwise be a somewhat alien world.  Rucks serves as a storyteller and historian for the viewer as the game progresses, serving as the medium for each major plot point in the game, and telling you about the history of places, events, and character as they become relevant to the story.  In addition, he provides commentary as you move through each level.  There is something shocking about the first time you hear Rucks provide commentary on what is happening in the course of a battle, something that seems like it could not be scripted, but obviously must be.Who needs to play this game?Once again, I would encourage all brands of gamer to check out this game.  Bastion uses great art, music, and storytelling to create an environment that you can be drawn into.  The action may not always be on par with some modern titles and parts of the game may not feel especially challenging, but the gameplay is always fun and the sliding difficulty scale will help keep you under pressure.  Bastion is available to purchase and download on the X-Box Live Arcade and on Steam.

content:
y 9, 2014
												Quite an amazing indie title. [Scroll down for Intro, Pros, Cons, Pseudocons, and Conclusion]Intro:Its controls are simple and utilitarian, anyone could pick it up and have a good time. Sometimes it's bad if a game is too easy; but I've never once felt that Bastion was too easy. Bastion is a piece of art which drops you (literally, often) into the middle of "The Calamity", which destroyed this town of yours, which you are completely unfamiliar with. The storyline is explained through narration. The narration, which reminds me a bit of Ron Perlman (Fallout narrator and actor), is extremely well done and the narrator himself is given his own characterization. Your own character never talks, but the narrator speaks through you, always in the past tense. When you do certain things, the narrator reacts. I chose a bone-repeater and a War Machete, and the narrator commented that weapons don't have to be complicated to be effective [along those lines, at least].The upgrade system for weapons is based on levels which are increased by finding one material and spending some in-game currency; and with each level you can choose one of two traits and it is always available to change it back. The distillery allows you to keep two drinks, but since only beneficial drinks were able to be served in town (I like it when the devs describe game mechanics, even if it isn't perfect. It adds character to the town) you can choose perks from the drinks, including an increased crit rate at full health, more health, a larger radius to collect money, instant crits at very low health, and many more which I have forgotten or not unlocked.The story keeps me intrigued, with this mysterious town, and my gradual learning of what happened. I am excited to play more.Pros:Nice artwork, simple fighting and controls, non-punishing mechanics, nice story, cool narrator. A nice variety of combat choices. It isn't ever edgy, inappropriate, or brutally violent for no reason. Kid friendly, but was designed for adults. Many challenges and upgrades to work for.Cons: It's an easy game, which would bore me if it wasn't a good game.Pseudocons [NOTE: These are cons which I included to warn those that may not like this particular developer's choice. I love Fallout 3, for instance, but some may hate that you can't earn every perk and get 100% in every skill] : A very basic level-up system, which has no real permanent choices. There is no real choice in the storyline, ie, it is linear. Most of the game is just mashing click to attack, right click to range-attack, shift to block/parry, and f to heal: potentially repetitive combat.Conclusion: If you are new to Video Games, or if you are a veteran, you'd like it. Great gift for kids or your S.O.

content:
ber 23, 2014
												Bastion: The first game made by Supergiant Games. Also the first amazing game they created.Bastion's a hack and slash action-adventure game, and a great one at that. You play as "The Kid", who stumbles upon the Bastion after the Calamity's wiped pretty much everything out. Your job? Restore the Bastion. You'll go through a relatively short, but well written story, with a small amount of replayability and lots of challenges along the way.Pros: -Great soundtrack-Great story-The game looks amazing with the color/lighting scheme-Amazing narration-Somewhat challenging achievements for the completionist-Many different ways to play the game, from difficulty to weaponsCons:-Not too much replayability - After NG+/Score Attack, you're pretty much done.Overall:Easily in my Top 10 Favorite Games. A great soundtrack + stellar narration + variety of playstyles + a great story + a fantastic looking game? That's a combo for a successful game right there. At $15, it might seem slightly overpriced, but take my word for it - It's not. That said, if you can pick it up for even a penny less, do so, as you for sure won't regret it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												Figured i'd write a little something since this game is on sale.First of all, as far as indie games go, this is one of the best, let's go over what it has to offer.+ Top quality soundtrack.+ Beautiful, and mostly hand drawn art style.+ Narrator is a nice touch, with a very fitting voice, wich means fantastic storytelling.+ An excellent system to increase difficulty (wich comes with rewards of course).+ A total of 11 weapons (that come with upgrades) and a distillery building that provides you passive bonuses.There are some arguable negatives.- Game is quite short.- Not much replayability (offers a New game+ option and a "survival wave" mode where you get to discover each of the character's story).I had have to edit the review a bit. I'm just not satisfied with what i said, take the above as a short version so to speak.First of all a critical thing i forgot to mention in my short review is that you use two weapons at once. That means you can kind of build your playstyle based on two weapons. Other then that: the storytelling that is backed up by the narrator has a good attention to detail, he'll say certain things if you fall in a certain area, he'll say something if you kill all enemies in a certain section of the game etc.To make a spoiler example: You can "adomesticate" certain creatures and keep them in the bastion. At some point in the game you get invaded by the Ura's, one of my pets that was fighting the ura died. The narrator promptly said "Our woodpecker friend, he don't make it.Apart from the attention to detail part, the game narrator has his own charm, his own way of speaking so to say wich i found deserved mentioning. The writing also was very well executed, one area stuck to my head in particular. Jawson Bog (light spoiler follows)Jawson bog is the area where the kid (protagonist) loses hope, he goes trough some hallucinations, basically playing small segments of previous areas again with an altered dialogue that was spokem previously by the narrator. For example at the start of the game you find a shield in an old distillery, then you learn to use it against some turret like things. The first time the narrator comments about you using the shield to your advantage to "counter" the turrets, in the hallucination however he says "He has the nerve to flash the shield he just stole, he's a petty thief. The owner of the distillery is also there, just turned to... some sort of stone i think it was, anyway he's dead, that's the point. In the "original" segment you can hit him and the narrator comments about you putting him out of his misery, in the hallucination he says "Would you look to what he did to poor Rondy"I Think that's about it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
1, 2013
Amazing Gameplay, Suffering StoryGorgeous, hand-rendered art utilizing creative, luscious settings and vibrant colors to set the mood. Fun and unique gameplay coupled with a beautiful and memorable soundtrack. There is a lot to love about this visually arresting game. As fantastic as Bastion is, there were a few things I had problems with in terms of storytelling.They touched on some sensitive subjects that could have worked well with the story but fell a little short. Basic gist (spoilers abound): Group #1 is part of a community that historically committed atrocities upon a rival community, Group #2. Group #1's resolution to make peace with Group #2 and right wrongs was to...kill a bunch of people from Group #2 and cause more destruction to their home. The narrative was written in a way that everything that happened to Group #2 was self-inflicted, despite it being the player character's fault. That part could have been removed and the story wouldn't have suffered.The mechanics, art direction, and soundtrack is what makes this game great. The story itself is told over and over again in movies and shows time and time again; a group seeks power by destroying and the oppressed is (rightfully) angry and seeks to avenge their own. No justice is served for the oppressed group and, by the end, it really feels like the game was saying "it was their own undoing" which is morally wrong. It had a lot of potential to tell a deeper story, possibly one of redemption, but they dropped the ball on that.6/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
y 8, 2015
												I usually avoid Hack & Slash games, but Bastion is special. Instead of drowning you in endless grind, the designers kept it short & sweet. This allows story to actively drive the game all the way through, rather than merely serving as punctuation. The smooth, standout narration deserves your careful ear, as its backstory adds so much depth to the overall experience. Bastion is one of the few games which enticed me to seek out other's analysis on its themes and philosophy afterwards.The cartoonish, hand painted world blends together to defy the sterile, methodical aesthetic many isometric games suffer. It's cute how these gorgeous tiles and assets fancifully fall into place just a few steps ahead of you, all in theme with the recollective nature of the story. The only jarring result of Bastion's isometry is you can only move in 8 directions; not granularly. However, the important thing is weapon aiming is granular.I won't lie, there were times I found the combat frustrating, but it did improve as I levelled (and equipped) up, and by the end, I was even enjoyed it. I also appreciated the fact that you have a good old fashioned hunk o' metal shield. As in, one you have to actively face the enemy and raise to counter with. The combat is definitely more interesting for that decision.Besides, Bastion is worth it for the music alone.

content:
30, 2012
												Original review by 17 year-old Luke: "A narrator who compares with even Morgan Freeman, challenging gameplay and a deep story - with a unique storytelling style. If you have working hands: play this game."While 19 year-old Luke agrees, I feel as though there's more to say, since looking back at Bastion: it still feels like one of my most significant gaming experiences of ever.That viewpoint is perhaps somewhat nostalgic; this was one of the first real PC games I played back when I was still primarily a console gamer. So I will look back on it with that same sense of importance as Assassin's Creed 2 or Uncharted 2, the first two PlayStation 3 games I played.Nevertheless, there are elements of this game that make it recommendable to anyone, despite its personal significance to myself and the close friends who played and discussed it with me back then.Firstly, the narration is exquisite - and yes, past-luke, it does compare to Morgan Freeman. The narration really draws you into the world quite quickly, and although I don't have a vivid memory of the world that the game was set in, I do have a vivid memory of the (protagonist) kid's adventure through that world. The narration is your first contact with that world, right into the game's ending moments - which I won't spoil, but I will say that they are very well crafted from a storytelling perspective.Secondly, I said the game had challenging gameplay. I'm not sure why I said that really. I did die a few times, but that was just because I wasn't used to playing with a keyboard and mouse more than anything. As James (M!dD3) points out in his comment, the gameplay is straightforward and simple, with a wide array of weapons to choose from and experiment with. And for those who want more out of a game's challenge - there are indeed way to buff your enemies in the name of bragging rights.For me though, the gameplay wasn't a prominent factor. More important was the music, the soundtrack is amazing and undefinable by common genres. I've heard it described as "acoustic frontier trip-hop", so....yeah. Lovely. I still listen to that soundtrack today, and everyone I've encouraged to listen to it has loved the sounds: from friends my age, to adults, to grandparents.However, a game's soundtrack isn't rated by the quality of the sounds alone; in-game that is an irrelevant quality. But the music fits the game perfectly. I can still recall the chilling hammer-on-stone clangs of "mine, windbag, mine' as I entered an eerie stage and began to learn more of the truth of the strange world. And don't even get me started on "build that wall" and "mother, I'm here" - or better yet, their lovechild: "setting sail, coming home", to this day one of my favourite songs.The artstyle is equally captivating while in game, there's a certain childish element to the designs that mix with the seriousness of the plot - summing up the kid's overburdened mindset perfectly. There's a reason that kid looks so melancholy on the game's cover art.And I suppose that brings me to the final element that I mentioned, the game's "deep plot". Yes, well, that's one way to put it. Let me just say the decisions I made in that game hold true to the way I intend to continue to view my failures and embrace the future for the rest of my life. That is by no means an overstatement, or some pretentious interpretation of the game's plot. This game is simple and important, that's all there is to it. So, as past-luke rightfully said: "if you have working hands: play this game."Storytelling: 1/1Plot: 1/1Gameplay: [who even cares, just play it]/10Visuals: 9/10 (impressively beautiful, but not the recommendation-point on this one)Soundtrack: 11/10 (the music itself is 100% recommendable, even if you don't play the game - check it out right now if you're reading this)Do I get a boner just thinking about this game?: Yes/Yes
