content:
er 27, 2011
												"A really great example of what a game should be. Original, interesting, and fun!"  (Dec 27, 2011)I still really enjoy this game. There's no sugarcoating it. This is one of my favorite games of all time and it probably had an influence in my life choices. Looking at the game closer, everything about it appeals to me. I love the character design, the music is above fantastic, and the scripting is amazing. The game mechanics are pretty smooth too, but that wasn't the thing that made this game one of my favorites of all time. The characters became a part of my life while I was playing this game, and not to sound like a crazy person here, but I connected with them all on an emotional level. Every single protagonist made me wonder about my life choices. I'm including Zulf in the pool cause I believe that he is in fact a protagonist, but that's an argument for another day. The Kid is the character that really makes this game. You befriend him as the player. The Kid isn't some faceless hero that you can imprint your own desires on to. The Kid, is The Kid, and everyone in the game recognizes that. The Kid has a personality, yet he's quiet the entire game. Again, I could rant about the similarities and differences that The Kid has to Link from LoZ, but that's an argument for another day. The kid, different from Link, existed before you started to control him. He had a mother and a life of his own. The Kid had feelings and dreams that the player can experience through dream snippets that make a separation possible between character and player. Rucks' narration also helps separate The Kid from the player, but when it comes down to it, this game is beautifully written and I can't stress it enough that this game is worth your money and time.Have a good one,CoffeeGoat

content:
, 2014
Must Play not only for Indie FansBastion is a top-down action adventure and the first title by Supergiant Games. It takes place in a dystopian, destroyed fantasy world that is nevertheless colorfully painted. You play as The Kid, a mysterious young man with white hair, and are aided by an omnipresent narrator that dynamically narrates your actions and is also used to deliver the game's lore to you in a very natural way.The gameplay focuses on a combat system based on dodging and rolling. It features an arsenal of melee- and long range weapons that all work and control differently, including a warhammer, dual pistols, a flamethrower and a machete that can also shoot blades. You can customize your experience using a variety of light RPG elements like weapon upgrades, an active ability(like a spin for the hammer or an AoE attack for the flamethrower)and passive boni that you receive by drinking different kinds of liquor you can unlock with experience. There is also an option to make your game harder and receiving more XP in return and a New Game+ Mode.Bastion is an interactive piece of art. The handdrawn art is gorgeous, the soundtrack is among the best ever heard in videogames, and the gameplay synchronises really well with it.

content:
r 16, 2013
												Bastion is an amazing indie title about world after apocalypse. You control silent protagonist which is narrated by someone who has replaced his vocal cords with  chocolate candy and that voice guides the protagonist through levels. Throughout progression you find 2 human survivors and 4 pets that will accompany you in Bastion when you return from your quest. I liked the part where you picked up Zia, the  singer. Her song is so beautiful that you don't want her to stop, but unfortunatelly you have to. I think it's the best episode in the whole game. The story is quite interesting and engaging, because you'll care about your new found friends and pets. Gameplay is quite fun, you run around and smash various creatures with your weapon of choice (mine was Brushers Pike and Mortar) and retrieve Cores and Crystal shards to make Bastion functional again. You get quite big weapon arsenal and passive abilities (which comes in the shape of alcohol) to chose from. If you wondering whenever you should buy it the answer is yes, definately fun, aestheticly pleasing and good quality product. 8/10

content:
y 8, 2015
												I usually avoid Hack & Slash games, but Bastion is special. Instead of drowning you in endless grind, the designers kept it short & sweet. This allows story to actively drive the game all the way through, rather than merely serving as punctuation. The smooth, standout narration deserves your careful ear, as its backstory adds so much depth to the overall experience. Bastion is one of the few games which enticed me to seek out other's analysis on its themes and philosophy afterwards.The cartoonish, hand painted world blends together to defy the sterile, methodical aesthetic many isometric games suffer. It's cute how these gorgeous tiles and assets fancifully fall into place just a few steps ahead of you, all in theme with the recollective nature of the story. The only jarring result of Bastion's isometry is you can only move in 8 directions; not granularly. However, the important thing is weapon aiming is granular.I won't lie, there were times I found the combat frustrating, but it did improve as I levelled (and equipped) up, and by the end, I was even enjoyed it. I also appreciated the fact that you have a good old fashioned hunk o' metal shield. As in, one you have to actively face the enemy and raise to counter with. The combat is definitely more interesting for that decision.Besides, Bastion is worth it for the music alone.

content:
er 27, 2011
												Let's begin with a disclaimer: Bastion if really freaking hard to describe.At its core, it's a top down action game with RPG elements, and at that, it does its job. The game plays like a charm, and most of the weapons are fun to use (even if I found myself liking the ranged options more). The whole game feels extremely tight and polished.Where Bastion really shines, however, is its story AND the way it is presented. Every action you take, even some really meaningless ones (being hit by an enemy in the first level, breaking crates) are commented by the ever present Narrator - if you ever played Portal and liked how GladOs reacted to your actions, you'll like this, too. The story is very good, too, and among a plethora of brown and bleak post-apocalyptic scenarios, I feel the colorful fragmented world of post-calamity Bastion is a refreshing spin on an over-abused genre.With how little it costs, seriously, you just owe this game to yourself. And your friends, possibly.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 10, 2014
												Bastion combines a wonderful mix of story, art, music, and gameplay all in a way that feels unique to itself.  The game starts you off with little direction but the narrator's voice as you get used to the controls, combat system, level flow, and most importantly the signature level design.  Every environment is Bastion "builds" itself from the ground up around you creating a very unique take on the "fog of war" style exploration you commonly see in strategy games.  Story-wise all of this is the result of some far-flung calamity that literally destroyed a good chunk of the world.  This puts the story's focus half on keeping up the progress of the Bastion's buildings and exploration of what's left around you.The graphics are wonderfully rendered and everything looks like a mix of semi-realistic 3D and hand-drawn sprites similar to a sort of top-down version of Braid.  Despite the bleak undertones, the colors are vibrant even in the darker levels and every place feels both desolate yet full of life as you see what's become of the world around you.  All of these are explored via your home base- the titular Bastion which acts both as a hub for missions, power ups, weapons, and side-quests, but also serves to both tell and fill in the holes of the story you missed through the narration that goes on throughout the levels.There are only four named characters in the game counting the protagonist, but all of them are surprisingly well-developed for how little any of them actually speak.  All of them have special reactions to pretty much everything you bring back with you on each trip and each has a backstory to explore through special bonus levels.  While interaction with them is minimalistic at best, you really grow to know who they are and care about their well being just as much as in games where you spend most of the story talking to them, which is quite the accomplishment on part of the frankly stellar narration.For how much of the game you're going to spend in combat, it sometimes feels like it takes a back seat to everything going on around you.  However, you'll never get distracted from it and each of the game's unique weapons has its own bonuses and downsides making no combination (you can take two with you, plus one special move of your choice) a bad call.  It really calls to create your own fighting style and do what suits you best.  Due to how you can upgrade any weapons in a variety of ways, there's really no wrong way to go into battle and it's always fun.  What makes things more interesting is that depending on what weapons you pick, how you choose to go about a level, and even how well you're doing or whether you decide to simply derp about, the narrator has a response to pretty much EVERYTHING you do, which adds a bit of flavor and life to the game that feels a lot more like you're actually being watched and having your story told.The soundtrack of the game is just as varied as everything else in it and always manages to hit the perfect mood, particularly with the wonderfully done vocal songs.  Many levels or situations have their own music and no two songs really feel the same or reused whenever they appear.Overall Bastion is a wonderful experience that takes roughly seven to ten hours to complete in one playthrough.  It's not a long game, but at the same time it's not any longer or shorter than it needs to be.  But you'll be thankful for that because it means you can easily play it again.  If you ever see it appear in sales or the Humble Bundle as it's often wont to, I highly suggest picking it up if it even sounds remotely interesting to you.

content:
4, 2015
												Play this Game.I bought Bastion back when it first showed up on Steam and I played a while but I never got the chance to finish. Recently I was looking for something different to play so I thought I'd fire Bastion up again and give it a play through. I love this game.Bastion is about a boy who "wakes up" in the middle of what the game calls the Calamity. Your story is narrated as you (this boy) progress through levels that build themselves around you. This should not be confused with procedurally generated levels, rather there's a hint of where a path should be and as you move, tiles form up around you. This is a pretty cool effect even if it's totally linnear. As you progress the story deepens, you find new weapons, upgrades, secrets etc. to battle your way through the game's enemies with a goal of restoring the Bastion, the game's home point. I never found the combat to be particularly challenging, with enemies brodacatsting attacks well before they happen and picking up fairly predictable patterns to counter. Your weapons and skills are more than strong enough to handle everything the game throws at you. You will have the opportunity to make things harder on yourself as you complete more peices of the Bastion if you wish. Weapons can be upgraded at the Bastion's forge, adding extra damage, or critical chance etc. You'll also be able to switch out skills and buy power up type items to help you along. And at the end you'll get to unlock a new game plus mode which adds a little replayability.Level design is pretty cool, as I mentioned above the world forms around you as you move along. Sometimes leading to dead ends, sometimes leading to secret areas containing upgrade materials, or new story items, even companion type characters. It's worth exploring every corner you can in these well built, beautifully rendered, but often very small areas. The story itself is at first just a narration of what you do as the game's hero character, but soon enough you'll start to feel it coalescing into something bigger. As you play, the game's narrator continues to tell the stories of the boy and various survivors of the calamity. This takes place in the game itself along with aquiring items to learn about and that help tell the history of the Bastion and it's home world and the people who inhabit it. Once things begin to move the story progresses quickly and in my opinion is told pretty masterfully. Now, Ive heard of people complaining about the narration of the game. Saying that he's too involved, or too in your face. That he never shuts up and they just want to play the game. I'm sorry to say that you can't shut the narrator off for those of you who may find him annoying. But on the other hand, he's the one telling the story, and Bastion is a story driven game so you need the narrator. I personally loved listening to him, the voice is pleasant, smooth and to me at least was nothing close to invasive. The narrator is integral to the game's story being told so you'll just have to deal with it and even if you don't like listeing to him I'm sure as things go on you'll at least be interested in what he has to say. The story itself is emotial, fairly deep and told really really well.As is usual these days the game is short, around 6 hours I think total with potential of a couple more if you complete the optional mini games. But the fact is the story is fully told in this time, so you get a feeling of completion even though you it's a short play through, and with new game plus you can double the play value and still have fun.Bastion, also has an epic sound track. "Zia's song", and the end theme "Coming Home" are two that stick out in my head. I believe the game even comes with a copy of the sound track if I remember corrctly. In conclusion, Bastion, is a beautiful, short, story driven game with an excellent story and great original music. It's inexpensive and worth a play through. Give it shot I'm sure you'll dig it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 16, 2015
												"Abstract" "Indie" games is where all the (K)ool Kids are. Just about recently, gamers are regularly met with a surfeit of these indie games that have a history of HYPE. Too bad most of them turn out to be vaporware or pretentious garbage. But there is that minute gleam of light that promises quality. Supergiant Games, thankfully, ends up being one of the few that actually develop decent games. Bastion, the game in question, is not one that should be adjudged "decent", but rather, astounding. Far from flawless, as this game is locked at 30 frames (Just, why?), but an overall stellar game that is worth every penny, or whatever crap currency you wield.Meet the Kid. One of the handful of survivors that has endured the Calamity. This catastrophic event brought the whole world to ruin. He sets off to the Bastion, where he is greeted by Rucks, the Stranger, with words claiming that the recent disaster can be undone. By constructing the Bastion back to health with monument cores and shards there are odds of restoring Caelondia and its neighbor lands to a time before hell unleashed, hence the title of this game. Throughout the Kid's travels to seek out the materials needed, players will learn more about the world and its people and you get to learn the backstories of the few survivors you come across as the game progresses. It might seem engrossing, but the story is where Bastion falls shortest. The journey with the Kid was complete in every angle it is viewed in, but it was also rushed from start to end, and had inadequate time to develop. Build-up starts to occur profusely around the last third of the game, only to conclude in some half-baked ending that proved to be unfufilling. Despite the mediocre narrative, Bastion is a feast for the eyes and ears due to it's gorgeous presentation.It is not an overstatement when it is said that this game has the potential to be sold solely on it's presentation. Hell, some have avowed that they bought the soundtrack before the damn game. It's just that damn delicious. Bastion's visuals is where that abstract tag comes into play, because it is most certainly what most reckon to be unconventional. The playing stage constructs itself as you tread along the path and the camera is complimented by a shiny filter, and other things I won't bother typing as it's better experienced than read. The soundtrack, done by composer Darren Korb, is brimful with impressive songs that seemlessly attach to the rest of the presentation. I'm not one that gushes over video game OSTs, but this one is pretty damn good, and I'm convinced everyone that isn't a moron agrees.If only it wasn't locked at thirty frames...that idea bothers me way to f****** much.Even with such wondrous superficial values, a game is crap if it isn't fun, and it is relieving to know that Bastion succeeds in this fundamental aspect too. Not much can be said about it however, it's just the average action-adventure game with a few tweaks that enable it to distinguish itself from the rest. The Kid can be equipped with 2 weapons at once and he has a "secret" move, and by, of course, playing the game (no way), the Kid is met with unlocks in his arsenal and attributes that gradually form him to an impetus of destruction by the end of the game. Sounds a little, unamusing, but this is without the mention of the copious ways one can up their game. The game played vanilla is laughably easy, but there are shrine idols that can unexpectedly rise its difficulty, which is recommended. There are also Vigils to complete for moneys, and wave-based side missions to earn more moneys and achievements, and a New Game Plus option that actually bears fruit! All of this will keep many entertained for a appreciable amount of time, around 20 hours or so maximum.There's more to be said, but I'm done. Bastion is a worthwhile game that I'm sure many have already invested their time in, and I hope people continue to pick this up. Supergiant Games is a talented developer, and they only demonstrate so with this installation. Where it fails in storytelling makes up in well-done game-structure and incredible graphics and sound. I'm looking foward to playing more entries from this group.Still haven't played Transistor at the time of this review, so I need to get to that quick.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												Is your world falling apart? Bastion can relate.       Maybe not in the mental state but taking place in a world that begins to crumble into pieces, Bastion manages to capture a beautiful unique scenery that has a quite amuzing arcade like gameplay. Positive    The story follows to be short but powerful, the game follows a young boy on the curiosity and discovery on what's happening to his world, and how can you stop it.   Captivating dialouge, you will enjoy this classical hit if you love the enrichment of emotions this story can and does indeed bring.      If you have enough money for the soundtrack i also highly reccomend you download that too. I'm not much on soundtracks, however Bastion does have an extremely rich and cultivating music producer. However the beauty if music is there is aways gonna be a song out there to enjoy....just not for everybody. Thus,https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLA6BDC6AA59483A76      I give you a quick link to hear some of the music so you can see for yourself if you would rather buy the game with or without it's soundtrack. Im kinda repeating mysef here but again, im not much of a fan for the soundtracks, thats why i recommend this one, because i just absolutely love it.(I'm listening to the ending credits song as i write this review!!!)Con      The game doesn't have much of a replaybility, I mean Bastion contains extra modes after the intial completion of the game isn't the type of game you can have 500 hours on....unless you enjoy the game that much but in hinde sight, it is a short game. Additional Info     The game contains multiple endings. Basion contains about as many choices as the size of one grain of rice, but very powerful in game choices you, the player, have to make.  It is not a choice making game like Mass Effect, but I just needed to add that because I still to this day regret all the decisions this game forced me to make. It's a balance of depression and joy that the presence of the choices were involved.In short, for any fan of an enticing, rich storyline with captivating scenery and ear endulging music, this game is a must have. Bastion is a definatly an 11/10 in my book and the music is a must have in your itunes library.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 16, 2014
												I cannot sing the praises of this game enough. I went into this knowing next to nothing, not even knowing how well praised it is. This has become my favorite game. The story is interesting and quite grim. There are no cutscenes or excessive text. It doesn't try to be a movie, it's a very subtle and gameplay driven story. The Narrator's voice gives Morgan Freeman a run for his money. The gameplay is fun and stays fresh for the most part. Interesting enemies and lore. The art style is beautiful, I adore how the land forms at your feet.And the soundtrack? Don't even get me started on the soundtrack. It is PHENOMENAL. I could listen to it nonstop. There is not a single song that is any less than the others. There are a few songs that have singers, which is usually a no-no in video games, but it suits the situation perfectly.The one thing that really bothers me only applies to you if you want to complete every little thing in the game like I do. It's no problem if you're a "finish the story then I'm out" kind of person. But the grinding. To buy every upgrade for every weapon, you have to beat Who Knows Where many times, or replay New Game+ multiple times. It gets stale, but I need to beat the Calamity Cannon training grounds, dammit!Bottom line, buy it. I'd wait for a Steam Sale (then again, I do for everything), but it's worth every cent. Supergiant Games deserves it so they can hopefully make more awesomeness. I can't wait to try Transistor.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
1, 2013
												An amazing game. Great story, good gameplay, terrific music and the best narrator ever.The storyline is quite cool, with a little element of choose your own adventure at the end. I just wish they expanded on the world of Bastion a little more, maybe with a sequel, it's a very fascinating world.The way the game progresses through the story is sort of simple compared to the extensive background of the Bastion. Most of the game is "Collect the core to build the Bastion. Oh no, Bastion broken, collect shards to rebuild. Not again, more shards please." The storyline is very linear and I feel that some other plot device could be used instead of cores and shards. The story was too formulaic because of this.The soundtrack, the art, and the narrator are fantastic. Every level felt awe inspiring, each environment looked incredible and well designed. I really loved that Rucks was used to narrate everything, it was a neat twist to story-centric games, and with Logan Cunningham's voice I didn't mind at all.The weapon system is very awesome and most of the weapons are mechanically very different, but there are some obviously underpowered and overpowered weapons (UP=Fang Repeater, OP=Galleon Mortar). Generally the weapons are mostly balanced sidegrades.The passive upgrades via Spirits is quite unique. There is also a faulty power balance among spirits too: eg. Leechade should always be equipped regardless of build. There aren't enough spirits to make different builds viable except for a tanky build and a high risk high reward build, which are both outclassed by the all around build. In all fairness the game isn't deep enough to warrant more builds than those.I really enjoyed the difficulty of the game. It's a very easy game until the idols are all turned on, now the squirt mobs instakill you when they die with the dropped explosives on death, the spinning gasfellas permaslow to a quick death, and the Ura move at godlike speeds; the fundamentals of the enemies change quite a bit. Regen god + Damage block god + Invulnerability god challenges on vs a really tanky and high damage enemy such as Pyth is really stupid though, it almost forces you to use the Galleon Mortar or other high burst damage.Don't take my review the wrong way though, the criticisms I've made with this game are very minor, the game as a whole is amazing and worth every penny.

content:
1, 2013
Amazing Gameplay, Suffering StoryGorgeous, hand-rendered art utilizing creative, luscious settings and vibrant colors to set the mood. Fun and unique gameplay coupled with a beautiful and memorable soundtrack. There is a lot to love about this visually arresting game. As fantastic as Bastion is, there were a few things I had problems with in terms of storytelling.They touched on some sensitive subjects that could have worked well with the story but fell a little short. Basic gist (spoilers abound): Group #1 is part of a community that historically committed atrocities upon a rival community, Group #2. Group #1's resolution to make peace with Group #2 and right wrongs was to...kill a bunch of people from Group #2 and cause more destruction to their home. The narrative was written in a way that everything that happened to Group #2 was self-inflicted, despite it being the player character's fault. That part could have been removed and the story wouldn't have suffered.The mechanics, art direction, and soundtrack is what makes this game great. The story itself is told over and over again in movies and shows time and time again; a group seeks power by destroying and the oppressed is (rightfully) angry and seeks to avenge their own. No justice is served for the oppressed group and, by the end, it really feels like the game was saying "it was their own undoing" which is morally wrong. It had a lot of potential to tell a deeper story, possibly one of redemption, but they dropped the ball on that.6/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												Figured i'd write a little something since this game is on sale.First of all, as far as indie games go, this is one of the best, let's go over what it has to offer.+ Top quality soundtrack.+ Beautiful, and mostly hand drawn art style.+ Narrator is a nice touch, with a very fitting voice, wich means fantastic storytelling.+ An excellent system to increase difficulty (wich comes with rewards of course).+ A total of 11 weapons (that come with upgrades) and a distillery building that provides you passive bonuses.There are some arguable negatives.- Game is quite short.- Not much replayability (offers a New game+ option and a "survival wave" mode where you get to discover each of the character's story).I had have to edit the review a bit. I'm just not satisfied with what i said, take the above as a short version so to speak.First of all a critical thing i forgot to mention in my short review is that you use two weapons at once. That means you can kind of build your playstyle based on two weapons. Other then that: the storytelling that is backed up by the narrator has a good attention to detail, he'll say certain things if you fall in a certain area, he'll say something if you kill all enemies in a certain section of the game etc.To make a spoiler example: You can "adomesticate" certain creatures and keep them in the bastion. At some point in the game you get invaded by the Ura's, one of my pets that was fighting the ura died. The narrator promptly said "Our woodpecker friend, he don't make it.Apart from the attention to detail part, the game narrator has his own charm, his own way of speaking so to say wich i found deserved mentioning. The writing also was very well executed, one area stuck to my head in particular. Jawson Bog (light spoiler follows)Jawson bog is the area where the kid (protagonist) loses hope, he goes trough some hallucinations, basically playing small segments of previous areas again with an altered dialogue that was spokem previously by the narrator. For example at the start of the game you find a shield in an old distillery, then you learn to use it against some turret like things. The first time the narrator comments about you using the shield to your advantage to "counter" the turrets, in the hallucination however he says "He has the nerve to flash the shield he just stole, he's a petty thief. The owner of the distillery is also there, just turned to... some sort of stone i think it was, anyway he's dead, that's the point. In the "original" segment you can hit him and the narrator comments about you putting him out of his misery, in the hallucination he says "Would you look to what he did to poor Rondy"I Think that's about it.

, 2014
												This review is brought to you by the wonderful Ponxha.Bastion is indeed one of the most captivating games I've played, gameplay-wise and story-wise.The art, the soundtrack, the narration. All of those elements made this game.GameplayBastion has lots of play styles to experiment with. The variety of melee weapons and ranged weapons gives you lots of different combinations to eliminate your foes. Speaking of enemies, each enemy has different ways to eliminate them and as you progress, you'll need the right tricks to cleverly eliminate your foes with the weapons you choose.StoryI'm not gonna spoil the plot for you, but I can tell you it is one the most heart-warming and clever video game story I've ever experienced. And Logan Cunningham delivers a very fine narration to top it offSoundtrackThe music in this game really immerses you into the theme of the game. Some parts of the story has successfuly shed a tear because of the beautiful music.Verdict+ Extreme variety of weapon play styles+ Beautiful and captivating art+ Surreal music+ Clever and well thought story10/10

												You play Kid who sets out on a mission to restore a land to which is once was. The story is what makes this one of my favorite arcade games. It is so immense and is unique is so many ways. This game extremely well done. The artwork is fantastic and the gameplay is just astounding. The game mechanics are so great, they are fairly simple and easy to grasp hold of. The narrator for this game is extremely talented, his voice is so pleasant and fits the game perfectly. The weapon system allows you make many weapon choices and combinations as well as certain and unique properties to go with those weapons. From a simple two handed hammer to what is basically a shoulder cannon that obliterates anything, the weapon system truly is amazing and fun to play around with. It also lets you choose between many traits as you progress in level. The game also provides mini challenges for each weapon which if you complete the assigned task you will rewarded with special items and secret moves for each weapon. The characters in this game is also what dragged me into this amazing game. Each one of them, even the enemies, are unique in their own way and their diffifulcty can be increased through the use of Idols which give enemies new abilities or a boost in health, damage, or their mechanics during battle. Another thing that I found neat about Bastion was that after you beat the game you can start the game from the beginning, but this time you will start out with the level your last playthrough, skills, weapons, and Idols. Overall this game is definitely a 10/10 for me.

content:
ry 9, 2015
												You wake up.  Stuff's falling apart.  An old guy starts narrating as you run around trying to figure out what the dink is going on.  This is the Kid's story about the Calamity.StoryWhile the actual storyline in itself has been done before, the presentation of it feels fresh and new as you discover what exactly is happening and everyone's lives beforehand and so on.  If I must make one qualm is the story is completely narrated to you during play.  That means while you're trying not to die fighting a boss or something, there is actual story being presented and it can be difficult for those who can't multitask to be able to pay attention and lose details.  It's also incredibly short, and you'll be able to do just the story in around 3 hours (not including sidequests) though the game has a New Game+ encouraging you to play a second time through with all your assets still in check.GraphicsSprites are sharp looking, environments lush.  I think the Kid's ingame proportions look a bit off from his artwork design but eventually you get used to it.  The enemy variety was a bit lackluster, which is a fault of the game being rather on the short side unfortunetly.  Sometimes it could also be difficult to figure out what you could and couldn't walk on leading to a fall, but I could've just needed my eyes checked I have no idea since it happened to me three times.ControlsThis game was meant more for a gamepad I feel, as the keyboard just feels rather awkward overall.  You can get used to it but never feels nearly as fluid as the controller with it's precise movement.GameplayI have to admit, blowing something up with a mortar or whatnot brings a shimmer to my eye.  Everything in the game feels organic, leveling your character, using materials to upgrade your (very large) cache of weapons and equipping tonics to your character instead of armor to grant special quirks.  Again as stated earlier, due to the game being so short it's necessity you need to play through the New Game+ just to be able to upgrade everything and even unlock the rest of the achievements since you can't play through any areas except Proving Grounds or character related arenas.  The Proving Grounds force you to complete a task using the specific weapon for each area.  My main issue is the difficulty ratios for each of them are wildly different, and sometimes you cannot complete a proving ground until you fully upgrade said weapon which is a tad irritating.  God help the Machete Proving Ground and it's stupidity.  If the game ever feels too easy, you can also add in Deities or Gods onto your person which grants you an experience bonus but adds difficulty and let me tell you, the game can be impossibly ruthless with those settings on.  The main flaw I feel of the combat system is the targeting, as you automatically target the enemy closest to you, but if you wish to switch to another target, any enemy between it and them will have to be manually cycled through leading to massive headaches due to the frequency of tons of enemies being dumped on you.  This also coincides with your shield use as you have to be facing the target to be able to use it and is just best left to dodge and roll then to block.SoundAt first I wasn't too enthusiastic about the music, but it has grown on me over time and I enjoy it.  Is it the best soundtrack ever? No particularly though there are some choice tracks in there that are worth listening too.  The voice acting is also done really well with the Narrator narrating everything from what weapons you equip to if you slip off a ledge and fall on your face.ConclusionA highly enjoyable game that is unfortunately really short, New Game+ or no.  Some small tweaks here or there and it could benefit greatly.  It also has some sort of 3rd mode of play which I never attempted involving some kinda scoreboard, which indeed this game does have leaderboards that surprises me but hey, why not right?

content:
er 29, 2013
												Bastion is a 2D isometric hack and slash that (unlike every other game I’ve ever played) works well with both controller and keyboard & mouse.  The first title released by indie studio, Supergiant Games, Bastion is a colorful, fast action platformer that is great for kids and adults alike.The Good:  Everything!  This game is %&@$ing amazing in every way!  The color, the way the story is told, the story itself, the music, the upgrades, the way the difficulty increases, the way new game plus is done, the artwork, the level design, the combat mechanics, the upgrades … you get the idea.  Literally everything is wonderful in this game!The Bad: The game is a little short and … Uhh … hmm, I am REALLY fishing for anything here.  OH! I got it! If you can find a way to make the hammer or machete work better than the pike I’d love to see how, the Brushers Pike/Spear is WAY better than the other two melee weapons.The Funky:  If you get it on Steam they give you a turret from the Portal games.  Talk to it and it will utter phrases such as, “sensory overload” and “location unknown.”The Verdict:  I really wish saying “10 out of 10” was not so over used because here it actually applies.  It is damn near impossible to get more entertainment for 15 bucks anywhere.  I realize this review is a bit short but the game has to be played to be understood and you’d be reading 2-3 more pages just for me to set the stage to talk about the experience that is Bastion.  Get it, play it, LOVE THE HELL OUT OF IT!

content:
er 9, 2014
												A beautiful arcade game with hand painted graphics supported by an interesting and original story and an even more original storytelling. The world you are evoling in is building itself while you are moving, and nearly every of your step is accompagnied by a deep and grizzly narator voice.The game comes with a variety of enemies using different tactics to bother you and of course with bosses. You on the other hand have a big choice of weapons and perks allowing you to always be best prepared for the next world you enter. Weapons are upgradable with "fragments' of the world you collect during your adventures, and you can also gain fragments while completing challenges related to your weapons or to the story.Expect 20 hours of gaming at least on your first run, and 10 to 15 more if you want to complete the "New Game Plus" mode and/or all Steam achievements.I highgly recommend it for anyone wanting to play a "different" arcade game.One last thing: there is no way you could not enjoy the beautifully crafted soundtrack.

content:
ber 16, 2014
												After completing Bastion, I realized that the ending is actually really thoughtful, you have two ultimate choices; restore the world to a time before the calamity which is the apocalyptic catastrophe that caused an outbreak in plague, monsters, and fighting factions, or evacuate the Bastion, the mechanical floating island that the old man, Rucks, and you, the kid, live on. That's the central point of the game, to get the Bastion back in working order, gathering shards and minerals to fix the Bastion.Along the journey, the old man, Rucks, narrates every move you make which might sound annoying but was actually intuitive because of all the context he is able to give. Later on in the game, you figure out that he's narrating to one of the Ura, a girl named Zia who comes to the Bastion after meeting the kid.I can't say much about the gameplay, as it's rather repetitive, shooting down enemies, blocking, and hacking, no depth to it. But the options you get in weaponry and special abilities and the leveling up make up for it. The game's design is isometric but also 2D, kind of cel shaded. And the floating islands which are part of the world was an interesting way to represent how society has turned out.Very good game though, with heavy depth in narrative.9.1/10

												Well ladies and gents, it took me almost 5 years but I finally Beat the game with 8 hours on record. With that said I took this game pretty slowly and I still beat it in 8 hours, Just keep that in mind. Let me just start off by saying this game is a work of Art, A Masterpiece. This game honestly shocked me, Before I knew who supergiant was, I went into this game thinking it was just some average indie game with little story. I thought that  you would just be  going from zone to zone grabbing these crystal shards until you finish the crystal. But slowly you start to realize it is not just that, you start to notice it is more complicated than that and encounter new characters and Items. As you get further and further into the game,the story starts getting thicker and thicker. The narrator (Who is absolutely fantastic by the way) Is pretty much telling someone the story of what you are doing in that moment and this mechanic is what helps guide you through some parts that you may not have figured out.As you progress you get these items which you use at the Bastion to upgrade the weapons which adds some variation is play styles.  My only complaint is that the OPTIONAL dream levels took so long and there was no checkpoints so if you died on the last wave you would have to restart and redo the last 20 minutes over again.9/10, excited to move on and play transistor finally!!

content:
, 2014
												"Bastion" - if it wasn't for my friend, who knows I love good stories and good soundtracks I might have never tried this game. He got me a copy, and I got addicted.In the game, you play as the Kid, who wakes up, and finds his world is literally falling to pieces. The ground shatters beneath him, it's like something is devouring the land like a disease. And that something is called the Calamity. The Kid has to find his way to the Bastion, a place created to gather any survivors in case of a catastrophy. A place that is supposed to save to world. But through his travels the Kid meets other people, finds their stories, and then discovers the horrible truth about the Calamity, and the Bastion itself.It's an action RPG set in a two-dimensional world with an isometric camera. Sounds simple, and boring enough, right? Wrong! The world is beautifully painted, colourful and vivid. There is a vast number of different enemies and environments. You also have a large group of weapons to choose from, and create your own style of fighting. For me, I always prefered the war machete as a melee, scrap musket as ranged, and squirt lure as a special ability. But there is a number of combinations, and everyone will find something fitting. The gameplay is mostly hack&slash, not gonna lie. But the story is just gripping. You do get involved, you do get attached, and at some point, you will be forced to make a decision. And it is not an easy one, it squeezed a tear out of my eye.The soundtrack deserves its own review... From blues bar sounding "Slinger's song", through the sweet notes of "Build that wall", exciting and fun "Terminal march", and the beautiful, heartbreaking "Mother, I'm here", this soundtrack provides about an hour of eargasms... I listened to it for two weeks non stop, after I completed the game, it's that good.Oh, and I forgot the best bit. The whole game is narrated by a deep, warm voice. With a hint of sense of humour, a lot of sarcasm, and plenty of emotions, the narrator, also known as Rucks, creates an atmosphere of a campfire story, being told to anyone who dares to listen.Will you dare?

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
y 5, 2014
												Bastion is an amazing game, with entertaining gameplay, a unique and beautiful artstyle, and most importantly an intricate, thorough, and moving story. The gameplay and combat is fairly straightforward, but the combinations of two weapons and a single skill can allow for many styles of play, and the lack of straight upgrades adds to this dynamic as well. Additionally, the system of leveling up was unique and further added to the styles of play, and the difficulty of the game scales well, with additional options to offer a greater challenge. Regardless of the engaging gameplay, Bastion excelled in its storytelling. Told through amazing narration, you experience the story of the world of the Bastion. The environment is defined by the artstyle and the soundtrack (which is definitely worth a listen). What stood out most to me concerning the story, however, was its ability to invoke an emotional response from me. As someone who usually plays games for just their gameplay, the whole story (and particularly the conclusion) I was surprised at how much I actually cared about the kid and the characters he meets. Overall, Bastion is definitely worth a purchase. Decent gameplay in an amazing environment with an engaging story made for a great game.

content:
, 2014
												9.75/10My freaking god, is this game good? Why are you asking that question? You don't have the time! Play it now!This would be 10/10 if it wasn't beatable in about 5 hours.You are The Kid. You awake in a world shaken by the calamity, the name should be enough for you to take a stab at what happened. But what really shines in this game isn't the amazing narration (which is 10/10) or the gameplay (9.5/10), but the ending. You have 2 sets of 2 choices, something unheard of until that point. SPOLIERS: The first decision is to take a half-dead man back home. Answer is simple, yes right? Wrong. For one, you have a leigon of angry people on your doorstep wanting to attack you, and for two... That man is the one who caused this whole mess. The second one is even harder. Do you revert the world back to before the calamity? Or adventure with the quartet you got to know over the game? If you choose the first option, the calamity will happen again. You will do what happened in the game again. You will choose that choice again, forever. If you choose the next one, you get to adventure with everyone you came to love other the game... The catch? The world stays in it's ruined state, forever.Get. This. Game.

content:
, 2014
												If you like adventure games, you must give Bastion a try.The art, aesthetics, music, lore, and especially the great narration all combine to provide you with a refreshing adventure experience. The levels are very detailed, and the routes you can take are assembled in front of you as you walk (you can easily fall off the map, which will result in some health loss). There are many destructable objects in the game - this is indicated by the object flashing red whenever you hit it (most objects can be destroyed).As you play, a narrator comments on certain things you do. For example, you may come across a mechanical bull and, if you decide to attack it, the narrator will say something like: "the kid (you) gave him exactly what he deserved." The music also changes appropriately when you are in the heat of battle.The controls are very easy to use, however, the feedback prompts can get annoying (for example, when you are at less-than-half health, the keyboard key "F" will appear next to your character, along with "heal." These button reminders can be helpful, as the game will prompt you to block if you are taking constant damage, however, it can become repetitive if you arleady have mastered the controls.There are many weapons to unlock, and you can equip two at a time; you can also use your shield by pressing/holding shift. Blocking right before the moment an enemy's attack hits you will result in an autoattack. You reflect enemy projectiles if you block with the correct timing. There are a variety of special "secret moves" available, and you can equip one - you have to have the specific weapon the skill is bound to equipped. Later, you will also be able to select things like drink passives (provide bonuses like extra health) or "god" artifacts that make enemies stronger, but also provide you with a bonus to experience. Everything is upgraded with experience that comes in the form of little blue collectibles. You can select between uo yo 6 different upgrades for each weapon ( 3 active at a time).The game consists of you collecting cores/shards in each level in order to bring the "Bastion" base to life - each core you collect usually opens a new building slot in the Bastion, allowing you to select which building type you would like to build first (ex: armory for equipping weapons and skills, or distillery for equipping passive drinks). There are a variety of buildings, each unlocked for building as you progress through the story.There are also weapon challenge levels, where you have to perform a task like destroying a number of items with the hammer within a time frame. Each challenge level has 3 difficulty tiers, and beating the time for that tier yields a prize (1st place is always a secret move). The learning curve is very good, however, the game can get difficult if you use a lot of god trinkets (to increase enemey characteristics) - I equipped a total of 4 and would die from most enemies within 4-5 hits.The game is very charming and I strongly recommend it if you like adventure games with very nice aesthetics and narration.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
er 24, 2013
												Bastion is, hands down, one of the best games I have ever had the fortune of playing. The visuals are incredibly appealing vibrant, fitting colours, detailed artwork. The western-theme nicely by the western music, which is very fitting on the game as a whole. The narrator's voice-overs and explanations for things are flawless and quirky, and make you want to hear more. The gameplay is great fun the combat, starting simple, becomes increasingly fast-paced and skill-based, especially when all idols are enabled for full difficulty. As you progress through the mysterious-yet-lore-heavy storyline, more weapons are unlocked, allowing you to play using different styles. You can eventually customize a "build" (a weapon loadout and some bonuses, called spirits). And the gameplay doesn't get old. Many games turn into grinding for levels, but Bastion encourages to play just to play. I am playing through the main storyline for the third time now, having already beaten it once in its regular story and difficulty, and another time in New Game with all idols activated. Replay-ability is very high, and I still have not grown bored of it.

												Bastion is a super fun, yet challenging game with a pretty art style and a good soundtrack!As to be expected from a Super Giant game, it is very story rich, with a fixed narrative. There is however, some agency you keep, since the narrator is only an NPC and his view can be challenged. But the gameplay isn't just follwoing the plotline-levels, there are the seperate weapon-levels as well where you can gather prizes based on your performance. To me, those were a welcome change and a fun challenge! I also liked that there is the possibilty to manually upgrade and put together your own weapon set. It encourages you to experiment with differnt fighting techniques and combos, which is always nice.All in all, I enjoyed playing Bastion and look forward to replaying it!

content:
9, 2014
												I just finished Bastion and really enjoyed it. Highly recommended!Gameplay: 8/10 -- Pretty standard stuff, i.e. everything you need from an isometric top-view style action-RPG. Not too complicated, not too simple.Visuals: 9/10 -- Really beautiful hand-drawn world, with a genuine "feeling" to it. Animation and cutscenes were also cool. I like how the world "came together" as you walked.Audio: 11/10 -- The music is fantastic and the "Narrator", accompanying you throught *all* the game, is just awesome. Easily the strongest aspect of the game.Story: 7/10 -- The story is OK, but there's too few characters (err, 4 of them!) and only a couple are really "explored". The world the game unveils is interesting, albeit tuned for "all ages" audiences.It took me about 12 hours to finish the game; the difficulty was quite OK, maybe a bit easy. I completed almost everything in the standard story-mode, and I didn't do any of "Game Plus", for the time being.Achievements (both in-game and steam ones) were quite finely tuned to my liking, keeping me reasonably motivated to play and earn more as I went.My sole problems were: (1) my no-name PS3-like USB gamepad wasn't recognised; typical... (2) Isometric top-view has the NE-SW and NW-SE as the two principal axes, so playing with WASD keys [N-S and W-E axes] was a little weird at first; but I quickly adapted.

One of them is that you are given too many weapons, Unless you plan on experimenting with the weapon load-out, You will usually stick with what works for you. Same with secret skills, which I hardly ever used while playing. Overall, an amazing game that opens up for you the more you play.

ber 23, 2015
												One of the better soundtracks I've heard in a very long time, along with the Uncharted Series, Ori and the Blind Forest, and Skyrim. Combat is fluid, the levels are well designed, and let us not forget that guy narrating your every move. He's awesome.I will also mention that this is one of the more beautiful games I've played in a long time, reminding me a lot of said Ori and the Blind Forest. It's bright, it's dynamic, and the colors always go with the levels flawlessly.And this is all coming from less than an hour of gameplay.I'll probably re-write this review later on, when I have more time in the game, but I have an inkling this will end up being one of the better games I've played in recent days, if not my life.So, far, my first impression is %100 positive. Can't wait to see more of it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 12, 2016
Bastion is an action adventure set in a wonderfully colorful hand-drawn surreal world. It is accompanied by a very unique soundtrack and a stunning narration, which reacts to every move of yours. The both story and action pacing are well tuned.What I liked:+ wonderful and colorful, hand-drawn surreal artstyle+ one of the best narration performances+ a fresh style of narration, which comments everything you do with your character+ amazingly unique soundtrack, described as "acoustic frontier trip-hop" (I told you it's unique!)+ the action and arcade plattform elements were varied up with different weapons, each with its unique fighting style+ all the weapons are customizable, allowing for further variety+ the world builds up and crumbles around you as you go and the story unfolds+ the length was just right with around 10 hours to not become staleWhat I disliked:- if you go for the challenge areas in the game or even one step further and replay the game in NG+, you will get a repetitive experienceVerdict:  MUST BUY!  Bastion is an indie action adventure game breaking many frontiers. A unique, refreshing and fascniating experience.

												In my opinion one of the best Indie games ever made. This psudo- Action RPG hack and slash game was made back in 2011 by Super Giant games. The game centers around "The Kid" gathering materials to fix the Bastion, a floating safe haven, after a Calamity happens that leaves his country in ruins occurs. Along the way you will collect several weapons that can change your playstyle. The game is entirely narrated and can the narrator will react to actions you do. The story is intriguing, and the hand drawn graphics are beatiful, even in for the current year. I highly recommend everyone who likes action and isometric games with a good story to pick this up.

												A unique aspect to Bastion, and possibly the reason of it's positive reception, is how the game engages the player: instead of having dialogue boxes, you have a voice narrating your every move in the game, whether you're countering enemy attacks, switching your weapons, and even falling off cliffs or dying. This gives a persistent idea that even the simplest action you take in the game is meaningful, an idea that I guarantee you'll enjoy.A small catch is that Bastion doesn't offer much aside from the first playthrough, but that's still a 10-20 hours of a good game, mind you, and this game definitely worth the price.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 7, 2014
												Kid finds the Bastion on Steam sale...It welcomes him with a familiar, yet fresh style. Its landscapes like an oil painting, its soundtrack envelopes the world beautifully and animations are elegantly sleek. Certainly a strong argument that games can themselves be a work of artHack n slash... kid's seen it before. But not like this. Elegant combat mechanics and a hearty arsenal that continues to grow throughout the game - each with their own distinct niche and style. Hard to comment on balance... kid seemed to believe that some were stronger than others, but friends found otherwise. Certainly reassuring to see each weapon come with its own learning curve of sorts. But kid can only pick two... that and the shield on his back. Game's not that cruel though... kid can change loadouts, and even change the upgrades themselves for free - allowing the full enjoyment of exploring different combinations to suit their style without punishing the decisions. Certainly more forgiving... than the calamity...About that... this story ain't anything new. It doesn't twist and turn, but is elegantly spun with nothing more than the guiding sound of a rustic narrator to weave the story together as the world itself continually weaves beneath the kid's feet. Every now and then the plot will be augmented with a single, simple, yet beautiful drawingBlack potions also help the kid to... swing things in his favour in a pinch. A single special ability. Balance is definitely more questionable here. Use the Calamity Cannon multi-shot ability and come tell me the other ones match it. Passive bonuses from the distillery (and my... special stash) futher enrich the level of customisability and allow the kid to really carve the game in his styleSure the kid's seen games like this before. But what it does, it does to near perfection. It burrowed into the kid's library and found a special place in its heartI guess you could say it found the Bastion

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
, 2016
												Years after its initial release, Bastion still stands strong as a fresh, entertaining approach to storytelling. Good games usually show off dazzling graphics, super fun gameplay, or memorable quests; truly great games sometimes even contain strong characters or engaging plots. Rarely does a video game story transcend its medium, however, and also carry emotional weight. Bastion is lush and beautiful, but it's also heart-breaking and soul-searching. This is the sort of prophetic adventure that everyone should experience. Strongly recommended.

content:
r 1, 2015
												I think it's about time I write a review for what is probably my favourite game of all time.Bastion is something that I view as the pinnacle of games as an art form. Not only does it have great art in many forms (music, aesthetic, the writing of the plot and the narration), but the main instrument of that art is still the gameplay. By this point, you probably already know the main "quirk" of the game: its narrator that comments your actions, sometimes important, sometimes trivial. However, Bastion goes beyond that. It's packed full of music that wouldn't shy away as a standalone album, visuals that would probably sell as paintings, and a story that warrants a book. And on top of that you have the action packed and surprisingly complex gameplay that serves both as a challenge and a tool to explore and reveal more of the game. The beatiful environment literally builds under your feet as  you walk. The story unravels through the narration of your actions. And the wondeful music supports it all.If you love indie games and somehow never picked up Bastion do it. You will not regret it.

												Similar in gameplay to an action RPG like the original Zelda, this game is worthwhile for any casual or hardcore gamer that loves a good story and a challenge.Hand-drawn art combined with an original musical score from a fabulous independant developer!  This is gaming at it's finest.  It isn't some sandbox open world, certainly, but what it does, it does better than most!I'd give this game a 10/10.  Exceptional.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
1, 2013
												This is quite possibly the best game I have ever played. Bastion presents itself as a work of art in so many different ways - from the visual style and narration to the combat and characters. Even though this is a short game, it is the only game I've ever played in which I immediately started playing again once I finished it. Not to mention - the story is engaging, making you care for the characters deeply. It is not only engrossing, but the added features like a Challenge Mode and New Game + Mode make this game easy to come back to again and again. I couldn't recommend Bastion enough.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 23, 2016
												It's all about the presentation, and it's amazing. The sound design is incredible (the soundtrack is spot on, and the narrator is legendary); the visuals are spot on: the world falls in place and collapses all around the main characters as he moves, mimicking the main theme of the game. I've been singing the main theme song for years after playing for the first time.Main game is 6-8 hours long, with a few extra stages focused on specific weapons. The game, however, can be replayed using different equipment combinations and, most of all, activating specific conditions to make the game harder (enemies don't drop potions, character is slowed after taking damage...).A must have, even if isometric brawlers are not your favorite genre.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 25, 2016
												Please...give me...more thumbs up buttons to click, for Bastion!!!This little game swept me off my feet and reeled me in at the first few seconds of starting it...First of all - Logan Cunningham is probably the best choice -ever- to be a narrator! His calm, deep and yet somehow so soft and pleasant voice follows the player throughout the whole game, and it could not have been a better 'companion'. The little parts of story that he tells you (well, or is telling Zia, in game, whilst The Kid goes and does the hard work) are a great little adition to your adventures. A more serious look at the past of that world, a bit of a comical insert (especially if you roll off an edge. *cough* Totally not me. *cough*), a touching, warmhearting little story...all of it is like a puzzle of vocal little pieces, that you have to put together to understand what has happened in the world of Bastion. And quite honestly - it's a brilliant way of making the player 'dive into the Bastion's Universe' and enjoy the game, his own actions during the game, whilst getting told facts or stories about the world (or the particular creatures that he's fighting currently. Second - the gameplay and looks. Amazing! As in...I could not have wished for better, from a little indie (and at the current moment - already OLD indie) game! It's rather beautiful and eerie, fluently swapping between various enviroments even on the same level. Yes, of course, the actions, combat itself will be simple and noone should expect some ultra-super-duper-gazillion-slashes-in-air-in-a-wave-like-motion-before-smacking-a-mob. But I still found it extremely enjoyable. Mostly due to the fact that you actually get such a weapon and playstyle variety, that even some of the new games pale in comparison! The mix and match of the combat possibilities is amazing. Third - the soundtrack! It's brilliant! Going from a heart-pumping rythm that makes you want to score the best...to an almost tear-jerker, as you listen to some more emotional parts of the story, told by the excellent narrator....If I knew it was so amazing, I would have bought it for the full price as well! An excellent little game that kept me entertained with every second I spent on it. And oh you bet - I will be going back into it, to get those achievements and explore the rest of the weapon combinations... :D

content:
er 27, 2016
												Bastion is a short game. It really only took me about 6 hours to go through every level and do moderately well at the challanges and achievements.While normally this is a problem for me because I like to get a lot of time out of my games as I'm pretty stingy when it comes to buying games, but it wasn't.Bastion took me for a ride I never expected. With an intriguing post-apocolyptic/ frontier theme, Bastion packs gameplay, story and asthetics all into one neat package that doesn't drag on spoiling the games like many other longer games might. All in all, Bastion is well worth the money and time it costs.I hesitate to call Bastion a masterpiece as that is not lightly given, but regardless, Bastion was masterfully done and I enjoyed every moment of it.

content:
3, 2014
												Surprisingly good and lovely game. It has a nice and intriguing story and cowboy-like songs and narrative that mixes very well with the intended atmosphere. I love the narrator's voiceover, btw. The game itself is easy and fast paced. You have to clear levels and, one after one, the story advances in the "city" (Bastion), revealling more details of future and past. You gain abilities and new weapons and customizations each level aswell. You can carry two weapons and one power at the same time, but can shift between all your unlocked weapons anytime at the arsenal buildings.On the last part, you have to make a choice (no spoilers) which leads you to one of the two avaiable endings. I recommend this game for pretty much everyone, specially those looking for a light story with soft gameplay elements and not so time/commitment requiring. I also recommend this game to children of 7+ yo; not because this game is silly or childish, but because there is no gore or explicit violence and kids could find the colorful themes and animations quite entertaining. At last, there's something on the moral of the story that parents could find inspiring and teaching aswell.

It really only took me about 6 hours to go through every level and do moderately well at the challanges and achievements.While normally this is a problem for me because I like to get a lot of time out of my games as I'm pretty stingy when it comes to buying games, but it wasn't.Bastion took me for a ride I never expected. With an intriguing post-apocolyptic/ frontier theme, Bastion packs gameplay, story and asthetics all into one neat package that doesn't drag on spoiling the games like many other longer games might. All in all, Bastion is well worth the money and time it costs.I hesitate to call Bastion a masterpiece as that is not lightly given, but regardless, Bastion was masterfully done and I enjoyed every moment of it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 25, 2016
												Please...give me...more thumbs up buttons to click, for Bastion!!!This little game swept me off my feet and reeled me in at the first few seconds of starting it...First of all - Logan Cunningham is probably the best choice -ever- to be a narrator! His calm, deep and yet somehow so soft and pleasant voice follows the player throughout the whole game, and it could not have been a better 'companion'. The little parts of story that he tells you (well, or is telling Zia, in game, whilst The Kid goes and does the hard work) are a great little adition to your adventures. A more serious look at the past of that world, a bit of a comical insert (especially if you roll off an edge. *cough* Totally not me. *cough*), a touching, warmhearting little story...all of it is like a puzzle of vocal little pieces, that you have to put together to understand what has happened in the world of Bastion. And quite honestly - it's a brilliant way of making the player 'dive into the Bastion's Universe' and enjoy the game, his own actions during the game, whilst getting told facts or stories about the world (or the particular creatures that he's fighting currently. Second - the gameplay and looks. Amazing! As in...I could not have wished for better, from a little indie (and at the current moment - already OLD indie) game! It's rather beautiful and eerie, fluently swapping between various enviroments even on the same level. Yes, of course, the actions, combat itself will be simple and noone should expect some ultra-super-duper-gazillion-slashes-in-air-in-a-wave-like-motion-before-smacking-a-mob. But I still found it extremely enjoyable. Mostly due to the fact that you actually get such a weapon and playstyle variety, that even some of the new games pale in comparison! The mix and match of the combat possibilities is amazing. Third - the soundtrack! It's brilliant! Going from a heart-pumping rythm that makes you want to score the best...to an almost tear-jerker, as you listen to some more emotional parts of the story, told by the excellent narrator....If I knew it was so amazing, I would have bought it for the full price as well! An excellent little game that kept me entertained with every second I spent on it. And oh you bet - I will be going back into it, to get those achievements and explore the rest of the weapon combinations... :D

content:
1, 2014
												This game is great. I was immediately surprised by how easy it is to play with multiple combinations of weapons and skills, especially since each weapon is rather well balanced, and it is both possible and feasible to use any combination you can imagine, except perhaps in the case of weapon-specific skills. Also, the dynamic narration and music (also dynamic!) really help with the atmosphere, and the decisions you make actually have consequences. This is a fine example of a game where YOU get to choose how you will play. Will you bring a pair of ranged weapons? Or will you go full melee? Maybe you prefer a ranged weapon and a melee weapon. This game lets you play with any combination! The roll ability especially adds to the gameplay, allowing you to gain distance for a ranged strike, or move in for a quick melee attack. It has been a while since I played a game this dynamic and fluid, and I happily recommend it to anyone reading this.

Maybe it's just me, and this game suits me well, but I've had one of the most awesome experiences in my gamer-life. The ending touches, but I won't be relling a word not to accidentally spoil someone's gaming experience.The second awesome thing is soundtrack. My Goodness, how I loved it! One day I've caught myself humming one of the motives during the working day - and than's when I realized i was in love with it. So grammophone was just another piece of game for me, perfect in itself.The other aspects of this hilarious game were also leaving only positive impressions - battle system, weapons upgrade system, spirits, special ablities, shrines with varying difficultie through the game, pets (omg, Squirt was sooo qute!) and so on. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
9, 2014
												This game was like a book. Rucks narriates the story as you go, and your actions will be mentioned sometimes as well. Sometimes when you die Rucks will act as if he forgot where he was at or his trend of thought broke. It's like someone sitting down and telling you the story of the calamity and the Bastion, except your imagination of how the story goes is right in front of you. It's the best story a video game has ever told. Besides the superior story telling, this game is lots of fun. You can find and upgrade weapons and use secret skills to help fight your way through the many trials and battles. Choose two weapons to fight with and one secret skill and head for the many floating islands the calamity has caused to find cores and shards. In the end, you have to make two very tough decisions. Chose whether you are a thoughtful and unselfish person (my choice), or if you're a self-centered person and you don't care what happens to your friends. All you want is the calamity restored. The end of the game made me almost want to cry. I think I almost did. There's no other game that can come close to the feeling I had at the end of my journey. NOTHING can ever come close. Now, I am battling with my throat. It's both a good and bad feeling. The ONLY minus there is to this game is that it was too short and not hard enough. This game can be completed in just two days. I stopped playing on the second day because I wanted to preserve the game, so counting that delay, I completed it in three days. The difficulty wasn't hard enough. On a scale of 1 to 10 of difficulty, I rate this game 6/10 (or simply medium). Fortunately, there's an extra mode you unlock after beating the game, and I still have to check that out. But I think that the original mode was a little too easy and short, but besides those two, I rate this game a 10/10! I hope a sequel comes out soon. It had THE BEST video game story and is my most favorite game as of now. I don't think any other game will pass this out, and if it does, not by much. I recommend this game to everyone!

content:
y 25, 2014
												Bastion is one of those games that will really stick with you once you complete it. Though the gameplay can be frustrating at times, especially because of the isometric viewpoint, the story is absolutely incredible. You explore the crumbling remnants of a ravaged world, trying to restore the Bastion, the one safe haven still available. As the game progresses, the story becomes even more engrossing, making it harder and harder to stop playing. The last few minutes, from the final portion of the last level to the end of the credits, is undoubtedly one of the best moments in gaming. Bastion is a phenomenal game, and I am still thinking about it even now. Definitely worth buying!

												Bastion is a Fantastic game and i enjoyed every single second of it! The game has great music and graphics. An interesting narrator that comments on your actions / decisions. And it also has a "Campaign+" Mode, Where you play the game over again with all of the stuff you got on your first playthrough. Its however a fairly short game that is not very challenging. However you can up the challenge by adding "Idols" Which makes the monsters harder to defeat, such as they attack faster, Take more damage on you, drop grenades once killed, Can't be shot with guns etc. This makes the game much harder.It's a fun little title which you'll beat in a few hours. I've read that some people have played it for more than 60Hours. I myself haven't come back to it yet but now im thinking about playing it once more as it was so fantastic!  The music and narrator of the game makes it a memorable experience that you most likely won't forget too easily :)

												Short version: It's a good game with an awesome atmosphere and audio. Honestly it's too good to be an indie game and for it's price I'd definitely recommend buying it especially if it's on sale.What is Bastion? Well for me it was not only a game, but also an experience like Journey, Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons and other similar games. An experience that I will always remember.The gameplay is pretty simple: you move around the isometric maps and kill enemies and occasional bosses using a variety of melee and long range weapons. A more interesting twist is that later on you can set difficulty level you want by activating up to ten shrines that give various buffs to your enemies. Playing certain levels with all of the shrines active can be quite challenging. There is also a "New Game+" option when you finish the game and since it has multiple ending it can be worth having second playthrough.The visuals are very nice. Each level is beautifully drawn and the level builds up under your feet as you move which makes the overall look even more appealing. The sounds. There are two sides worth mentioning. The music and the Stranger. The music is really good and fits the game great. I'd probably think about buying it if I hadn't gotten it together with Bastion in the Humble Bundle. The Stranger is this games most known feature. He is the narrator that talks about you and your journey with a deep and very nice voice. He is so popular they even made a Bastion announcer for Dota 2.All in all this game will probably leave a lasting memory and is a great experience. I have really enjoyed playing it and it's definitely worth it's price. I would definitely recommend you to try Bastion. You will not regret it.

content:
er 29, 2015
												So freaking good. Almost five years later, it's a timeless masterpiece that you just want to keep playing more and more. At its core, it's a pretty simple story but it manages to charm and captivate like no other. The voiceover narration embedded into the gameplay is so expertly done. The soundtrack is easily one of the best ever in any form of entertainment, creating a new genre by itself. Combat it very satisfying and the game encourages you to try out different weapon combos and experiment with upgrades. There's plenty of totally optional "proving grounds" where, even if you fail the challenge, you learn something about how to best use a certain weapon. It's really well designed. The the upgrading and weapons system is quite in-depth for a game that looks so deceptively simple and playful from its tone. Passive bonuses from potions are great. There's a dynamic difficulty system where the player intentionally makes the game harder for themselves in exchange for more EXP, which is genius.All the areas are diverse and different enough so that you don't ever feel like you're doing the same thing twice. The handpainted environments are drop-dead gorgeous, only enhanced by the amazing soundtrack.I could go on for hours, but just buy the game. It's that good.

												I have finished the game in normal mode, so it's time to write a review.If you expect a pure RPG like Runescape, this is not the type, but the graphics, audio, story, combat mechanics and effects are SO GOOD your money will not be wasted.This isn't a difficult game, you'll die once or twice, that's all.If you have time and money, just sit down and relax on some Bastion gameplay.+amazing story+awesome narration+mind-blowing graphics and fluidity+nice combat mechanics-not a "real" RPG, may be misleading-not too much freedom out of the story, however the story is very enjoyable-a bit too easy at times, and the save system may be frustrating (you need to finish the area before quitting)This game also has a touch of surrealism I enjoy.

content:
y 20, 2014
												Should you play Bastion if you haven't done it yet? In one word : YES. Gameplay-wise the game is very well done. You collect weapons, spirits, level up, upgrade you weapons, etc. The difficulty level is adjustable by use of idols : you practically invoke the gods who in return make your life harder :) . To be honest, i played the game 3 times using the idols just to get more achievements. It's a blast! To make it short, the gameplay is engaging and challenging at times. Now the best part of Bastion : it's music and graphics. About the music there is nothing to say except that it's gorgeous. You'll definetly download the soundtrack and integrate it in your playlist. The narrator does a fantastic job at depicting the story and describing your every action. The narrator is no more that person who talks only between mission. If you break a vase, he tells you that, if you defeat a boss, he's certainly got something up his sleeve to say. And all this happenes without becoming too annoying.The graphics are astounding despite the fact they are 2d (or at least the background is). In fact, this has an even more powerful impact on your perception than a game who has 3d graphics. Every detail in the game is finely drawn and you'll feel the urge to explore every nook and cranny just to see the vistas.So, what are you doing here reading ? Go buy the game!9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 18, 2011
												One of the most competent, enjoyable, and original indie games that I have played in recent memory. An Action RPG that blends the water-color paint style of Braid with the insanely addictive character building of 16-bit era games such as Secret of Mana, Bastion is an easy two thumbs up. What surprised me about Bastion the most was the unique storytelling format with an unusual, unexpectedly deep plot. The lack of multiplayer is the only significant issue, but at this price I have no reason to complain. If the developers could brew a sequel with multiplayer, it would be a classic for the ages.

												TL;DR: Buy it. Play it.I've owned this game for years. I don't know when or where I got it, but it's just been sitting in the abyss that is my unplayed Steam library. I finally got around to playing it and absolutely loved it. The graphics and soundtrack are perfect. The way the story is told is really awesome and fairly unique. It's not a very long game (I think it took me about 4 hours to finish it). Towards the end of the game I started to feel like it was a bit repetitive, but never once did I want to stop playing. The game is an absolute must-play and is a truly wonderful experience.
